reviewText:
look no further than Liam Neeson.  With Taken (which I have not seen) and Taken 2 (which I have), Neeson proves he has the intelligence, resourcefulness, cool composure, and presence to sell us on a new Bond.

  If the first Taken (as I understand it) was an efficiently violent revenge fantasy, Taken 2 is basically an efficiently violent "revenge for the revenge fantasy" of the first movie.  I will not regurgitate the plot here.  I refer you to Steven Aldersley's Taken 2 review for that.  Instead, I wish to pursue the strong Bondian elements that propel this fast, exciting flick, particularly Neeson's character's  (Bryan's) cool intelligence.  Bryan is captured and hooded , along with his ex-wife Lenore (Famke Janssen) by vengeful Albanian father Rade (Murad Hoxha) grieving for the white slavery mastermind son that Bryan killed in the first movie for attempting to kidnap his daughter Kim (Maggie Grace).  However, he is able to compose a mental map of his surroundings (Istanbul, Turkey) by listening to distinct sounds and calculating the intervals between them.  That way, he is able to convey a meticulous sequence of directions to Kim, who managed to stay safe at the hotel, so she can pinpoint his approximate location and provide him with a handgun to help him free himself and possibly Lenore.  I don't know if this is plausible, but it certainly seems ingenious.

  Even before all the action begins, we appreciate the precautions and weapons Bryan takes and accumulates (including mini-cell phones and other devices) to handle any dangerous exigency.  Later in the movie, even after being beaten and chained in a filthy basement, it's gratifying to see Bryan not only attempt to free himself, but also give those precise instructions to Lenore, and particularly Kim, to help him and them escape their predicament.  Realistically, both Lenore and Kim are fearful and uncertain what to do, but Bryan's cool CIA-operative professionalism helps keep them focused.  He may be retired, but Bryan is such a one-man assault gang, you get the feeling that Rade and his gang, despite their savage ruthlessness, never really stood a chance.

  Yes, Taken 2 is quite an enjoyable action thrill ride, but I am rating it about 3.5 stars for the following reasons: 1) as other posters have mentioned, much of the action, especially the taxi chase through the very narrow Istanbul street, was shot in that nauseating shaky-cam style that made it hard to follow the action sometimes, and made you wonder how Bryan, for all his skill, actually made it through alive.  I thought Kim was gonna collide with some car any minute - and her without a driver's license, 2) there's a slight whiff of xenophobia, especially in the depiction of Istanbul.  From a distance, it is a magnificent metropolis, but once the movie gets closer, you notice the extreme poverty and claustrophobia of the favela-like neighborhoods.  It looks forbidding.  The Turkish Tourist Board, probably just recovering from "Midnight Express"'s unflattering portrayal, now has to contend with this movie's, and later, ironically, the latest Bond flick Skyfall's depiction.  First the Albanians, now the Turks.  Europe doesnt seem like such a nice place. 3) you have what Roger Ebert calls the Fallacy of the Talking Killer, which states that instead of killing the hero outright, the villain wastes time boasting and talking about what terrible things he'll do to him, giving the hero a chance to retaliate.  If Rade despises Bryan so much for killing his son, why toy with him so long?  Yeah, yeah, you wouldn't have a movie.  So you go with it.

  Oh, whatever.  Taken 2 is nevertheless an efficient, sharp, involving movie with not only action, but also snatches of humor (e.g. Bryan's reaction to Kim's latest boyfriend, the taxi's barreling towards the U.S. Embassy - "The soldiers will get out of the way.") So what can we expect of Taken 3? Hmm, I know.  Kim and her new boyfriend Jamie (Luke Grimes) go to Bratislava and encounter a "Hostel" situation.  Bryan to the rescue!

  One more trivial thought.  My friend Ron Spiegel, who watched the movie with me, thought Rade looked like "the most interesting man in the world" from the Dos Equus commercials. Stay thirsty (for revenge) my friends!

I very much enjoyed this movie.  Maybe Taken 1 was a little better but Taken 2 was still great! (And, I will buy the DVD when it comes out.)  There is just something real special about watching Liam Neeson go after these brutal, murdering creeps.

This time the film begins in Albania, where the bodies are being unloaded from the airplane -- the bodies of the bad guys that Neeson killed in Taken 1.  As they are being buried, the grieving family surrounding the dead, the head guy and father of one or more of them, vows revenge against Neeson. (I mean, forget the fact that THEY started the whole thing by stealing his daughter.)

The scene shifts to Los Angeles, California, where Neeson's former wife is in the midst of a divorce from her second husband and the daughter is dating.  Neeson is leaving for a couple of days of work in Instanbul and invites them to join him when the job is finished.  As you probably guessed, all the excitement begins on foreign soil, as the bad guys go after Neeson and his family.

It is a great movie, with lots of action.  Yes, some things seem a bit of a stretch, but then (like I always say) the movie you really want to see is the one where a super hero beats all the odds and does incredible things.

Will these bad guys EVER LEARN?

In the previous movie "Taken" our hero Liam Neeson travels overseas and rescues his daughter from some kidnapers. These kidnappers intend on selling his
daughter to the highest bidder. Her father rescues her. In the newest movie "Taken 2" the mother has seperated from her new husband. She and her daughter decide to go on a business trip with their father to Instanbul.. The father of the killed kidnappers is planning on revenge. he has a group of Ruffians in
Instanbul to kidnap Neeson,the mother and the daughter. They suceed in grabbing Neeson and the mother but miss the daughter. Using his black-ops tricks he manages to escape. The hunt is on. Neeson reclaims his daughter and next has to find his former wife. This is where the wild chase scenes take pover. Fast
cars become paramount. Neeson places his daughter at the U.S. Embassy where she can be protected. There is now a confrontation between Neeson and the revenge seeking father. This makes for a stunning conclusion to the story. Be sure to see this movie.

I think it was well done with a descent story, good directing, but again it's hard to repeat such an incredible ride in part 1 for anyone.
Dirt bags are always an interesting type, they kill and rob people every day of the week but when someone gets them it's revenge time for killing theirs!  Never could figure that one out, but that's how it is, very much realistic I am afraid of especially with gangs or criminal groups.
Again good movie, go watch it.

I knew nothing about Taken when it was released in 2008, but it proved to be one of the best action movies I had ever seen. There was just enough information about the characters to care about them, and the action was intense and rather elegant.

That shouldn't surprise me because Luc Besson and Robert Mark Kamen wrote the script. Besson had previously grabbed my attention with Lon: The Professional, which is one of the best action movies ever made. La Femme Nikita was another notable triumph. I mention all that to explain why I was already sold on the idea of Taken 2 as soon as it was announced.

So, did it meet my lofty expectations?

The opening scenes were something of a surprise with Brian Mills (Neeson) interacting with his ex-wife, Lenore (Janssen), and daughter, Kim (Grace) extensively. I like that we are shown how Mills has grown closer to Lenore. In the original movie, she was cold and spiteful, but the two are clearly on better terms now that Mills has used his skills to rescue Kim from her kidnappers. It made perfect sense and rang true for me.

The plot is simple. If you remember Marko from the first movie, you'll probably know that he was part of an Albanian gang. In Taken 2, Marko's father is obsessed with avenging the death of his son. He's not interested in why Marko was killed, or that he was guilty of many crimes, he's only interested in seeing Mills killed. When Mills takes Lenore and Kim on vacation to Istanbul, Marko's father instructs his gang to capture Mills and his family. He partly succeeds, but Kim escapes.

The opening setup is quite long and thorough, and I remember thinking that more than half the audience were probably anxious to see Neeson get on with the task of eliminating the opposition in as many unique and violent ways as possible. However, once the action starts, it's relentless and intense. We see car chases, shootouts, fights, threats, brief torture, and a rapidly increasing body count.

Mills wants Kim to stay out of danger, but eventually enlists her help. I'm half expecting a sequel called 'Miss Taken.'

It's unrealistic to expect a movie of this nature to be completely plausible. After all, the basic premise is that a 60-year-old man is capable of defeating gangs armed with automatic weapons. The method Mills uses to escape his kidnappers is so simple that I have to wonder why he didn't do it about 30 minutes earlier, but I'll forgive that.

The ending was quite inventive, and paves the way for another sequel should Neeson and the cast want to reprise their roles a third time.

I did have a few minor complaints, such as the kidnappers talking in English when it's obvious that they would stick to Albanian. Another minor annoyance was the use of shaky cam shots throughout most of the intense action scenes. There's a fine line between adding excitement and losing track of the events on the screen. The line was crossed a few times.

Overall, I was happy with Taken 2. It delivered more of what I liked about the first movie and added depth to the relationships between the main characters. I don't think it's quite as good as Taken because we now know what Mills is capable of, and some of the pleasure of the first movie was seeing Mills demonstrate his unique set of skills for the first time.

Taken 2 definitely works better if you have seen the first installment. Some of the actions and dialogue are direct references to events from the first movie, and you will miss some of the humor if you aren't aware of past events.

Fans of Taken will be more than happy with this worthy sequel.

Two things to remember:

1) Never agree to go on vacation with Brian Mills.
2) If Neeson uses your taxi cab, you probably won't see it in one piece again.

"Taken" was, to me, the movie that threw Liam Neeson into the "action star" category. I know he was a Jedi knight at one point, but that was the movie that made it real. The story was compelling, the action amazing, and the entire thing was a thrill ride. While the story this time out is very unique (the relatives of some of the men he killed in the first film are out for revenge) and I loved where it came from, the execution of the whole thing faltered horribly.

While "Taken 2" will not let you lose faith in Liam Neeson's ability to kill a man creatively with his bare hands, the director this time out seems to take it as a personal challenge to change camera angles as many times as humanly possible during any action sequence. As a result, any time Liam is talking to someone, it's all calm and steady. The instant he moves toward a person to attack, the director takes the movie into an angle frenzy that lets you know there's a lot of action going on, but you'll never know what it is. It looks as if they didn't want to bother choreographing the fight scenes, so instead they just had Liam jerk around a bit and threw the camera into all sort of close-ups of elbows, shirts, fists, and such with sound effects. During a car chase scene, I counted 65 different camera angle changes in one minute, some lasting just a half a second close-up of a steering wheel, foot on the gas, etc. It's deplorable. At one point, Liam puts his hand on a guy's face and the guy dies, making it appear Liam killed him by sheer willpower. I am all for another one in this franchise (and they easily pave the way for a sequel at the end), but get a better director the next time out.

Liam Neeson reprises his role as the lethal, always alert agent Bryan Mills, in Taken 2, and I'm very happy he's back, this being a welcome action role return for Neeson.

The story follows the logical revenge plot of the villains' surviving Father, of who's sons Bryan took down in his determined venture to save his daughter from a network of slavers. This round, Bryan Mills enters Istanbul and his ex wife and daughter visit him just as the enemy is closing in.

FAST CAMERA CUTS: 24 cuts every 10 seconds?
Most of the action scenes of which there are plenty (car chase, foot chase, gun battles, hand to hand combat) directed by Oliver Megaton is up for debate. For example, when action begins, there seems to be a sequence of 20 film shots for every five seconds of film, resulting in an MTV like barrage of imagery. This can work if done right, but here, the action, although frantic and full of energy, becomes harder to follow for some viewers, myself included. Just think of the stealth take downs of Batman Begins to picture the style of elbow shots and hard to follow close ups, rendering the battle a series of hard to track motions that don't add up to a cohesive fight all the time.

It comes down to the cinematography, director and editor to make sure the audience can easily follow the action, but here, it's a flash of close ups of steering wheel horns, motion blurred elbows with the occasionally well done distance shots so we understand where the character is in relation to the environment and enemy, Thankfully, the firearm battles are done better, the car chase is overall exciting, and the final fist fight, against a very tough and formidable enemy, results in a well done hand to hand battle (though the editing still leaves a question mark at it's conclusion). The final fight works, because the majority of camera shots show the full body of both fighters, avoiding the extreme close ups of an earlier battle. Why do I mention all of this? Because Taken 1 delivered consistently easy to follow, really well done action scenes.

In the end, Taken 2 is an enjoyable follow up to Taken, and recommended for anyone who enjoyed the ever alert and ready to kick butt style of Neeson's Bryan Mills character.

Taken 2 ends up being a decent action movie. If they make Taken 3, bring back the editor and team from Part 1.

ACTION: 6/10. Plenty of energetic action, though the cinematography/editing is sometimes hard to follow, it flicks through film shots like a flip book. Not a good approach for action movies.
STORY: 8/10. Logical revenge plot and a well done story.
ACTING: 8/10. No complaints here.
OVERALL: 7/10.

Taken 2 is the follow-up to 2008's Taken number 1, which I bet you had no idea about. But it's true! Taken 2 is the long-awaited sequel to Taken number 1, and it proves yet again that Liam Neeson is so much more than a guy who saved some Jews in some black and white movie from a really long time ago. It proves that Liam Neeson is still an extremely viable and sought-after action movie star...you know, when more popular action stars like Michael Biehn, Dolph Lundgren and Lassie are busy with other projects.

In this installment of Taken, Liam Neeson, Maggie Graceless and Famke Johanssen are all able to reunite and have some family time in Istanbul (which is a peace-loving, Muslim city that used to be called Constantinople), which is downright offensive when you consider that Maggie Graceless is still playing a teenager at the age of 30 and that Famke Johanssen is way too old to pretend that she was ever Jean Grey or a Bond "girl." Anyhoo, though, reunite they do, and just when Neeson's character and Johanssen's character are about to, shall we say, fornicate in a quickie right before they have to take Maggie Graceless' character to the vet, the bad guys from Taken number 1 burst into the room, ending the anticipated sexual encounter.

However, they take Famke Johannsen's character hostage and sell Maggie Graceless' character into white slavery. The movie then ends rather abruptly after some clichd, action-movie developments: First, Michael Biehn, Dolph Lundgren and Lassie all make surprise cameos, which really interrupted the flow of the high-stakes drama in my opinion. Then, Neeson's character finally succeeds in saving both Famke Johannsen's and Maggie Graceless' characters, but, being women, they both get angry with him for "taking too long" to finally save them, and they slap him aggressively across the face for his efforts. Finally, in what I can only judge as a totally tasteless move by the director, Liam Neeson's dead wife, Natasha Richardson, is actually shown over and over again throughout the closing credits of the movie, which utterly failed to satisfy the director's apparent desire to have some kind of closure in the movie's plot.

Despite these problems, I can't wait to buy Taken 2 when it is released on VHS soon. In fact, me and my friends will have a sleepover party to celebrate when Taken 2 is finally available on home video. In the meantime, just disregard the extremely negative reviews of Taken 2 on sites such as Rotten Tomatoes because just because everyone says this movie s/u/c/k/s does not mean there is a consensus on this movie's s/u/c/k/in/g.

The first TAKEN was a ridiculous movie, with Liam Neeson doing amazing things, lots of killing and lots of unlikely globetrotting.  He got around Europe & Asia in a way that makes Jack Bauer's ability to move around LA in the show 24 look like he's dealing with heavy traffic jams all the time.  His ability to never be shot, and yet to never miss a shot of his own was almost laughable.  And his daughter, that he was trying to save, was one annoying brat that most viewers weren't terribly invested in saving.

TAKEN 2 has learned a few lessons.  Most of the film takes place in Istanbul...so there is minimal globetrotting.  There are still plenty of opportunities for scenic action scenes, but at least credulity is not stretched to the breaking point.  (Oh, in case you don't know...Liam Neeson plays a retired government agent with a "particular set of skills" whose daughter [Maggie Grace] and ex-wife [Famke Janssen] are in near continuous jeopardy and Neeson is frantically saving them and killing bad guys).  In this iteration of the franchise, the daughter takes a more active role...which is interesting, but doesn't make Grace's character any more likable.  The actress is in her late '20s, but her character is much younger because she doesn't even have a driver's license yet.  Not sure HOW young...but Grace tries to make her younger and it almost comes across like a woman trying to play a little girl.  ANNOYING.

And, as with TAKEN, this movie could benefit from an R-rating.  There is a lot of violence, but not blood. I don't need the blood for the sake of it...but the constant turning away from the results of what Neeson is doing makes the film seem anti-septic.  The GRIT is missing.  These are brutal films...but the PG-13 attitude makes it all seem a bit...harmless.  I think the film might be more thrilling if more seemed to be at stake.

The TAKEN films are a bit silly...no getting around that.  They are modestly entertaining...but there has also been a lot of potential left on the table.

First off the pure image of seeing an average of 4 stars for this movie baffles me. Why might you ask? Simply put the movie is crap. To start the director Olivier Megaton makes it look like the camera weighs a MEGATON!! The way he films the action is horrendous in this movie. He constantly shakes the camera and cuts right when a punch is landed to a different view and back and then cut again. You literally have to make out the fight in your mind which is very annoying when I come to see an action movie.

Story: Bryan Mills takes his ex wife and daughter on a trip to Instanbul when things take a turn for the worse. His ex wife gets kidnapped by Albanian relatives from the last movie (Taken which is a far better film) who want payback for what Bryan did. It's up to Bryan to save his ex wife and protect his family.

Besides the Action rant earlier the film is short, and has a fast pace which is a positive for this movie, because you wouldn't want a longer version of this catastrophe. However Liam Neeson is great in this role as always, Famke Jannesen is okay as Bryan's ex wife, and Maggie Grace is like 30 playing his daughter which is kinda funny because she is supposed to be like a freshman in college, anyway she is not good in the movie.  Overall the film is fast paced, dumb, edited to garbage, Liam Neeson is good, has a decent action scene at the end even though it's edited still kind of horribly, and it's a decent time waster movie but you should definitely not buy it.

Taken 2

 I told one of my pals that if he wanted to see a movie where the bad guys get killed in large numbers without a lot of plot to get in the way of the action, Taken 2 is the movie of the week for you.  I thought to steer him to more adult fare.  Instead he said Great, thats just what I want to see.  He is not alone this week.  Taken 2 massed a huge $50 million over the week end and a worldwide total which includes both domestic and overseas of $117 million.  This is on a modest budget of $45 million of which a goodly portion must have gone to star Liam Neeson.  When the people speak with such a unified voice I stand out of the way to avoid the stampede.
 The bad guys are truly the absolute dregs of human existence, soul-less Albanians who make their living enslaving women into prostitution.  The head bad guy tells Neeson that his beautiful daughter will be sent to the worst brothel we can find and be abused by the lowest kind of men.  It essence, it is a re-play of Taken, the 2008 hit with exactly the same theme.
 The beautiful daughter is played by the beautiful Maggie Grace who played the daughter in Taken.  Movie magic has Ms. Grace looking believably like a young collegian, which was easier four years ago than today at her advanced age of 29.  I thought she was about 20.
 Famke Janssen is back as the mom.  She gets kidnapped this time instead of the daughter and has an innovative horror committed upon her innocent self.  Janssen had her first acting gig on Star Trek the Next Generation and has had plenty of screen time both on TV and the movies.  She stared lately as Jean Grey in the X-Men films.
 Liam Neeson needs no explanation.
 Director Oliver Megaton (Colombiana, Transporter 3) re-joins his collaborators, writers Luc Besson and Robert Mark  Kamen.  All three of them worked on Colombiana, a fierce little action piece with Zoe Saldana as the vengeful killer.  Besson and Kamen also co-wrote The Fifth Element, one of my favorite movies of all time.  Besson also produced Taken 2.
 This three saw blade action flick is very well produced.  The chase sequences are good and there are a couple of excellent side lights.  One sequence has the daughter setting off hand grenades in Istanbul so captive daddy can figure out where he is by the sound.  In another clever sequence Neeson tracks the bad guys to their den by remembering the sounds he heard as a captive.
 But well done or not it is still rubbish, outlandish and violent with improbable plot twists that are plopped in from time to time to keep the body count up.  Think of The Expendables 2 done by people who can act, write, direct and produce better than most and you have the idea.
 But I am embarrassed to say that I quite enjoyed it.  I found the bloodletting cathartic, God help me.  And so did a whale of a lot of other people.
 The PG-13 (violence, large body count, no undue gore) film is over in one hour and 31 minutes.  James Bond is coming soon for those who appreciate their bloodletting done with a little more style.

Taken 2 is an action thriller that features Liam Neeson,who returns as Bryan Mills, the retired CIA agent who stopped at nothing to save his daughter Kim from kidnappers,in this sequel of the first film entitled,Taken. It also stars Maggie Grace,Famke Janssen and Rade erbedija - all of whom co-star to play key supporting roles. It is directed by Olivier Megaton.

After the events in Paris, family members of the men whom Bryan Mills killed while searching for his daughter, Kim, return to their hometown, Tropoj, Albania, for the funeral of the men whom Bryan had killed. During the ceremony, Murad Hoxha, the employer of the men and father of Marko, a victim whom Bryan killed by electrocution, states that they will find Bryan to avenge the deaths of their loved ones. When the father of one of the villains Bryan killed swears revenge, and takes Bryan and his wife hostage in Istanbul, Bryan enlists Kim to help them escape. Bryan then employs his unique tactics to get his family to safety and systematically take out the kidnappers, one by one.

Liam Neeson looks spiritedly enough in the role, and more than capable of another go-round should Taken 2 match its predecessor's success. Unfortunately,it is more of the same, except a little bigger and a little less invigorating. This sequel is simply made for Neeson to cater to his fans as it just provides the viewer heavy doses of action to entertain. Overall,it is just a passable and entertaining sequel and nothing more.

this is an excellent example of the modern multiplex hollywood genre that i call "magical heroism". it requires both that the hero have extraordinary mental and physical powers, and that the world in which the hero moves magically assists his exploits to unfold. in other words, it's complete junk.

two questions you can never ask yourself in a magical heroism movie are: (1) why did that happen? and (2) how is that possible?

how is it possible that a young woman without a driver's license can evade a dozen or more pursuing police cars? how is it possible she can shimmy along a ledge, or randomly throw three grenades in downtown istanbul without a SWAT team response? how is it possible she can ram all the US embassy security and end up in the embassy courtyard without a full throttle military smackdown? how is it possible for the hero to discharge at least two dozen rounds from a pistol without reloading? how is it possible he can sneak up on several guards and dispatch them all unnoticed? well, you're just shown the scenes of these things happening, so shut up and sit there.

why does the daughter use explosions and acoustic triangulation to find the location of her captive parents? (her dad has a cell phone; security forces can tower triangulate his exact location in at most half an hour.) why does the mother, bleeding to death from a cut neck, survive being dragged by her captors across the city? ("it will take 30 minutes for her to die," sneers the terrorist.) why does the hero let his daughter drive? why does a second chase car suddenly appear after the first one is demolished? well, why are you even bothering to ask? you're supposed to shut up and sit there.

the level of crass and clumsy fantasy required in a magical heroism film is the signal characteristic of the genre. it floats (if anything found in a toilet can float) because liam neeson is so inherently likeable, and famke janssen still looks incredibly hot three decades after her turn as a "bond girl". and yes, you do get to see some shots of istanbul, including the rooftop walkways and bazaar alleys that have figured in many action movies of the past.

the key to a magical heroism film is just to get you in the theater, or get you pushing the button to buy. then it's too late. you've lost your money, you've blown off other opportunities to live your life, you've surrendered control. you may as well shut up and sit there. it will all be over in a couple of hours.

Whats it about?

Former CIA operative Bryan Mills returns to our screens with the father (and crime boss) of those he killed in the first movie, seeking revenge and targeting both Mills and his family.

What did I think?

Quite simply this should have been called Taken Lite. A surprisingly logical premise justified the sequel but the general action from then on mirrors the original to a point where you're left wondering where the "meat" was.

Its not bad  in fact its quite fun and worth seeing  but theres a lack of originality that leaves it feeling like quite a short romp that really had little point to it other cashing in on the popularity of the awesome first flick.

Quoted simply its the Diet Coke version of Taken. Less calories, less filling.

Kind of gets off to a slow start but I guess you could call it a slow build. There is a nice suspenseful sequence in the middle of the film involving the daughter setting off a series of grenades in a bid to find her father. The daughter departs from the typical damsel-in-distress role and gains points as a kind of accidental heroine. I disagree with previous comments about the fast-cutting in the action scenes. I think the fast cuts serve to disorient the viewer, creating a kind of confusion that happens during an adrenaline rush. I do agree with other commenters that some of the killing blows seem a bit anti-climactic - and maybe even a bit strange - but that's a minor gripe. There are a couple action movie cliches that occur toward the end of the film, but all-in-all it's not a bad action film.

Good, but could have been better. Seriously, these type of movies can and will have unrealistic scenes, this is no exception. So, having said that, it is a good movie, but could have been much better. The acting is good and solid, I think it is the director that needed to be better. After the deaths of the kidnapping Albanians in the first one, the "father" of one of them acquires the help of some more thugs to seek out Bryan Mills and take revenge at all costs. Bryan has to go to Istanbul and while there, he is surprised and "taken" back by his wife and daughter's sudden appearance greeting. Soon, after leaving his daughter at the hotel unattended in a foreign country (after what happened in the first one), his wife and he decide to go out on the town nearby. He is watched by informants in the hotel lobby and upon leaving they are followed. Both eventually get caught and are taken to a hideout not that far from the hotel. Lucky for him because his daughter is an excellent tracker. Bryan and his daughter escape to the American Embassy where in a Taxi, they run the barriers after being shot at by multiple machine guns and weapons and survive unscathed. They sit in the courtyard, heads down, discussing what to do next. Oh, he must make a call to let the Americans know that he is not a terrorist and not to shoot him. THIS after running through the barricade that is put up specifically to stop all traffic! lol See what I mean by unrealistic? Director mistake, big time there. Bryan eventually makes it back to his nearly dead wife at the hands of the left over Albanian kidnappers and takes any means necessary to get her back, alive. This includes meeting the father that headed up the "revenge" group and making an offer to him to leave his family alone or else suffer the consequences like that of his son and his recent cohorts. The Albanian gives a second to think about it, but considers that an insult to his son's memory, picking up an unloaded gun and pulling the trigger on Bryan as he is walking away. lol Bryan, turning around probably already knew this scumbag would not honor his own word and throws a bullet at him, then pushing his head back on to a robe hanger, end of story, right?
Well, for the time being anyway.....lol
All make it back to America safe and sound with new one time one movie boyfriend of daughter having a nice little ice cream talking about the future.

Once the characters, tools, and plot of a film are established, we know what to expect the next time around. It's hard to make a sequel as good as the original, because the surprise factor is more difficult to create. Taken 2, like so many sequels before it, falls victim to this fact. However, with that said, I thought it was a very fun movie, and it did introduce a few new ideas that made it enjoyable.

My only complaint is that in one scene, seemingly every police car in Istanbul is in exactly the area where he is trying to escape and there are literally no other drivers in this district... only cops, all coming for Liam Neeson, in response to a shooting. But then later in the movie, there are long, violent, drawn-out gun fights in a building, for a very extended amount of time, and yet no officers ever show up on the scene. But hey, what do you want from an action film, right?

Boring shoot 'em up movie with no plot.  Husband and wife are captured by terrorists.  Of course, nothing can hold Bryan Mills, so he breaks himself free.  Somehow, he was able to hide a cell phone...at his feet on the ground...and his captures didn't notice.  He was able to call his daughter who ran on roof tops lobbing grenades so Mills would know how close she was.  Of course, no one noticed her running around tossing hand grenades.  Mills, with his sidearm, takes out a dozen soldiers armed with automatic weapons.  And what is with this Mexican stand off thing in fights when Mills and an adversary both end up pointing a gun in each other's faces...and they stop to look at each other.  Right!  Like either one of them is going to blink, let alone pause.  The end was silly.  The captures still had Mills' wife, but they took after Mills head on, instead of using his wife as a pawn by threatening to kill her unless he gives up.  The action scenes were terrible...they were edited into tiny little flashes of action that were impossible to follow.  This filming/editing technique still could not cover up the fact that Liam Neeson is miscast in this type of flick.  He has no fight moves....no game face.  I went in with low expectations, because I thought the first movie was ok, but Taken 2 simply horrible.  I won't be watching Taken 3 unless it's free.

Other than having most of the main actors from the original movie Taken 2 is nothing like the original.

In the first movie there are elements of a bumbling dad trying to unite with his wild and young daughter. The ex-wife is believably jaded although still action-movie-helpless and when the daughter is kidnapped then the experienced dad beats up the foolish bad guys. There is at least some attempt at character/plot development.

Taken 2 really jumps off a cliff. The daughter is stupider, the wife is more helpless and "dad" is now super-hero-amazing. An added bonus is that the patriarch of the bad guys is not nearly as smart as the original-foolish-bad guys.

Highlights:
If you are ever lost have your teenage daughter use hand grenades to signal her location. No one will get hurt.
If you want to learn how to pass your permit test go to Istanbul and drive "...faster, faster..." while crashing into cars.
The ultimate way to kill the last bad guy is to use a combination of the Vulcan-death grip and a shower head.

This is not an awful movie but a lot of effort has been made to make it one.

TAKEN 2 suffers from bad acting, bad plotting, a bad antagonist, and a bad concluding act. The third act came and went so fast that I thought "surely that's not it?" and then the movie ended. The movies was just a collection of action tropes linked together without any soul, charm, or inventiveness.

THE FILM: TAKEN 2 is a blatant rehash of its predecessor that also has a marked reduction in filmmaking quality, yet it is still watchable due to Liam Neeson's work in the lead role. Bryan Mills is back in this sequel to surprise hit TAKEN, and this time he's been able to get a little more involved with his family while also doing security work on the side. While on assignment in Istanbul, his wife and daughter show up unexpectedly, but unbeknownst to them, survivors of the Albanian family that Bryan massacred in the previous film have tracked him down in order to exact their revenge. What this film makes evident is just how contrived the plot of the first one was, and ups the ante in terms of the lack of believability. While the film starts off in similar fashion to the previous one, there is a plot element which becomes convenient later for the sake of having an action setpiece. This setpiece is a car chase through the streets of Istanbul that has Maggie Grace's character drive like a maniac all while being chased by the Albanian baddies. Other ridiculous elements include a laughable scene where Bryan has his daughter throw grenades into public places so that he can approximate her location relative to his by how long the sound takes to reach him. It's absolutely ludicrous, but still funny at the same time. However, the real negative that can be taken away is the change in shooting/editing style, courtesy of director Olivier Megaton. While Pierre Morel attempted to give TAKEN a modicum of comprehensibility, Olivier Megaton opts for shaky-cam and haphazard editing (frame-cutting, rapidly changing angles) that obscures what seemed like some decent fight choreography. Even the visual aesthetic has been changed to reflect this more down-and-dirty style which, while effective at conveying a sense of urban dirtiness and griminess, gave the film an ugly sheen which put a damper on what could have been a relatively fun adventure. Still, despite all of this and the fact that all of the supporting characters come off as perfunctory, Liam Neeson is able to sell this concept yet again. Overall, its quality doesn't live up to its predecessor's fine production values, but fans of the original should find enjoyment.

THE EXTRAS: There isn't quite as much supplementary material this time around, but there is a rather significant extra which sheds some light on what film this could have been, versus what was delivered to theaters. The extra I am referring to is a 25-minute alternate ending in which Famke Janssen's character is successfully rescued before Liam Neeson takes out the bad guys at the Turkish bathhouse. The reason it was changed is because Bryan Mills' motivation for going back to kill the villains would be stronger if his wife was still captive. I actually agree with this choice in theory, but the execution makes it clear why the chase scene in the final version looked so shoddy. Since she was in the taxi with Bryan and Kim, they would have had to digitally remove her and/or cut frames with her in it, adding confusion to an already choppily edited sequence. Beyond this, the extra features are quite ordinary. There is a 4-minute featurette with Sam (one of Bryan's CIA buddies) giving information on the various tools in Bryan's working case. Interesting, but nothing you couldn't find out elsewhere. There are also a handful of deleted scenes, although only two of them would have added anything to the overall film in terms of character development. Also, similar to the last film there is a picture-in-picture Black-Ops Field Guide. Finally, there's a 5-minute FX featurette with Liam Neeson talking about his character and reason for doing the sequel. He mentions that he enjoyed  the creative space he entered in the previous film, but also that he thought the concept for this film was believable. Sure, whatever you say. When it comes down to it, the alternate ending is the only worthwhile extra.

OVERALL: When it comes down to it, fans of the previous TAKEN will probably see this no matter what anyone says. And who can blame them? It delivers everything that they liked about the first one. As far as the supplements go, the alternate ending alone makes this Blu-ray worthy of a purchase. Recommended especially if you like these types of movies.

I have been a fan of Liam Neeson for years  and I have seen just about all of his movies.  The first movie I saw him in was Schedulers List and I was impressed with his acting.  He has now become somewhat of an action hero type of character, which I love. I enjoyed Taken #1 so much I had bought the DVD.  I did not see Taken#2 at the movies but I immediately purchased it which I got for a bargain price.  I enjoyed Taken #2 even more than the first Taken.

This one has a similar theme but in this one, the father of one of the kidnappers in the first Taken seeks revenge for the killing of his son by Bryan Mills, ex-CIA operative (Liam Neeson).  Mills had some important business to do in Istanbul and invited his ex-wife and his daughter along in order to spend some quality time together.  Unknown to Bryan Mills, the revengeful father has set a trap to kidnap Bryan and his daughter and ex-wife in Istanbul.

Needless to say, this group of killer thugs has made a tragic mistake in underestimating the skills of Bryan Mills.  The movie begins a little slowly, but it is not long when all hell breaks loose as Bryan hunts down the kidnappers.  There is plenty of great action in this DVD.  I thought it was at least as good as the first Taken.

Wow!  Im so glad that I gave this movie a chance.  I originally didn't want to bother because of the negative reviews, but after watching the trailers for it, I knew I wanted to watch it.  Anyways, this movie is spectacular!  It has so much action, suspense, and intensity.  This movie is definitely a thriller.  And, if you saw the first movie, this movie is truly the perfect sequel to it.  It picks up right where the other movie ended.  Also, this movie clearly leaves an open door for a Taken 3, so hopefully they will make another great sequel.  And lastly, this move includes an alternate ending if you're interested.  But, I have to say that the theatrical version of the ending is much better than the alternate ending.  In conclusion if you love Liam Neeson, action, suspense, and a great story, then this movie is for you.

This movie at least triples in enjoyability if you look at it as a parody of the first movie. It is 90 minutes of pure hilarity, and kept me giggling through the entire thing. Some of my favorite moments **SPOILERS BELOW**:

-Watch Liam Neeson, resident badass, engage in the most awkward flirting known to man. 'I want to...not punch you? Does not compute.'
-Oh no! It's a standoff, guns drawn! But it's okay, Liam, go ahead and make your phone call to warn your daughter, we'll just wait here patiently!
-Maggie Grace throwing grenades in the middle of Istanbul - no one really notices, no one really cares
-They finally have Liam Neeson, resident badass, in their clutches! Rather than use the chains in the room, they'll tie him up with...plastic zip ties?? After all, they need those chains to hang Famke Janssen upside down like this is Hostel 4. They'll then leave Liam Neeson totally oh-so-securely fastened with his plastic zip ties! What could possibly go wrong?
-One of Maggie Grace's pursuers WHACKILY STRANGLES HIMSELF on a clothesline during their rooftop chase - SHENANIGANS!
-Maggie and Liam manage to decimate their pursuers in the car chase scene, yet Liam insists on crashing full force into the American Embassy before taking a leisurely stroll back to where they originally had Famke before they moved her...but she's still there?
-Poor Famke Janssen plays dead possum basically the entire movie
-The whole movie ends with the family having milkshakes at the beach and chuckling about Liam possibly (probably) killing Maggie's boyfriend.

So don't go in expecting another movie like 'Taken'...expect a movie making fun of 'Taken' (although I'm sure that wasn't the original intent) and suddenly, the movie is still terrible but also hilarious.

I did not have high expectations for this movie going in (the critical reviews are not very good - see for instance rottentomatoes) but it was on sale at bestbuy for $2.99 (on DVD, theatrical release version) so I said to myself why not? In reality this movie is not half bad - certainly not as good as the first (in both storyline or execution) but it's okay. The main problem I had with it is the somewhat strange filming/editing of the fight scenes (which are a little confusing/chaotic sometimes and hard to follow). I think they did that to impart those scenes a certain sense of speed - Liam Neeson is, after all, somewhat passed his prime for this kind of action. Then, there are some other issues with the story - a little spoiler alert here! - which really make the suspension of disbelief quite challenging: [like his daughter driving that stick-shift taxicab like a pro after she failed to pass her driving tests a few times (!?), the driving into the embassy  - ludicrous and physically impossible to do that there, navigation by throwing grenades in the city and other ridiculous little things like that]. All in all, a somewhat plausible story, fairly acted - and for the money - I'll give it four star.
probably wouldn't watch it twice but was fun and entertaining, good pace, good fight scenes and some creative scenarios/ideas thrown in the mix

The last time we saw Kim Mills, daughter/ victim in the first "Taken", she had been rescued from human traffickers by her estranged father Bryan. And it wouldn't have been unreasonable for her to be severely traumatized by her experiences in that earlier film. But the Mills family are "amicably separated" and little Kimmie is about to take her driver's test, as well as dating a boy who Daddy's not sure he approves of. But while the three are tourists in Istanbul, the father of the human trafficker who Bryan killed in the process of revenge for Kim's abduction has just buried his son in Albania and now wants to show Bryan that "payback is a moyobets"--or however you render it in Albanian. Papa and his remaining sons catch up to Bryan and his ex while they're out shopping, with Kim deliberately back at the hotel so as to "re-matchmake" Mom and Dad. Bryan knows that some sort of attempt may also be made on Kim so he calls her to tell her to take preventative measures. Too late--she's already managed to elude attackers there and now proceeds to dash to Mom and Dad's rescue, coached by Bryan over the phone. Running across rooftops and throwing grenades every which way. At one point during the high-speed chase after reaching Bryan, Kim is the driver so Dad can shoot back at pursuers. These scenes turn out to be how the action adventure genre might approach the "Daddy's Girl" phenomenon. It's almost anticlimactic in the final scenes when the girl actually takes the driver's test back home. The DMV examiner thankfully doesn't know that this particular "applicant" has recently roared all over Istanbul like she was Steve McQueen's daughter in a "borrowed" Mercedes taxicab.

If you like infantile macho power fantasies like Batman and GI Joe but don't think they take themselves seriously enough, then Taken 2 is for you! Liam Neeson stars as a paternalistic old white guy who massacres reams of treacherous brown people to protect his helpless, emotional womenfolk. It's even better than the stories I come up with when I play with my AR-15 in the bathtub! (And while I watch Taken 2, mom doesn't nag me to wash behind my ears. I SAID DON'T TREAD ON ME, MOM!)

It does have its weak points, though. For example, sometimes the women talk. Also, a fair number of people in the background of some scenes got away without so much as an elbow to the throat (what kind of message is that sending to our children???). And worst of all the action scenes are shot like an abstract European art film, asking you to ponder random blurry shots of elbows and the backs of heads as they fly through the frame. It's almost as if they're trying to get us to reflect on our increasingly dull familiarity with violence; the scenes blur into an incomprehensible flurry of meaningless carnage individually as well as collectively, leading the viewer to ask, "why?" But I guess I should have known they'd try to brainwash me into thinking about stuff: the director's from FR*NCE.

And speaking of things that are for snobs, there are SUBTITLES in this movie. I don't watch movies to read words! Luckily it's just foreigners who talk in letters, so all they're probably saying anyway is "I surrender!" Just shoot him in the foot seven times already, movie, jeez louise! Yeahhh, like that. Now impale him on something. Zoom in close! Yeahhhhhhhh. Push it in there with your big, strong hands. Now pick up his blued finish 9mm Beretta 92F. Grip it firmly in your thick, gnarled fingers. Thumb the clip release. Gently! Gently.

I'm sorry, I got distracted again. Between typing this review and the vicarious rage thrill from watching Taken 2, I'm all tuckered out! To summarize, if you're a red-blooded American male, you and this movie go together like high-capacity firearms and Jesus.

One of the things that you find in some sequels is the Ridiculous premise used to get the movie to happen. Revenge is always a good motivator for engagement:

Murad: I have come to take you to Tropoje to face you to the people whose lives you have ruined. To give them justice.

Bryan Mills: You mean to give them revenge.

Murad: If it gives us peace call it anything you wish.

Having said that, all kinds of Kick Buttery ensues...They Threatened the people he loves and weren't prepared for the consequences! Excellent film, I'd like to think that I don't just buy everything that comes out so the fact that I invested in this film (and the first) actually lends to how good a film I believe this to be. I'll see a movie in the theater, wait a while, see it on HBO or similar and think "Man, that was a really good film!" and then add it to the collection. By then of course the price has dropped Substantially which is an even bigger bonus! Regardless of my methods or reasons, I stand by my assessment - great film.

Spoilers:
Murad: [Bryan has him cornered] What are you waiting for?

Bryan Mills: You have other sons?

Murad: Two.

Bryan Mills: And if I kill you, they will come and seek revenge?

Murad: They will for sure.

Bryan Mills: And I will kill them too. You can change that. You can go home, live your life, enjoy your sons, your grandsons.

Murad: And my other son, Marko: the son you killed... am I just supposed to forget it?

Bryan Mills: No, you'll just have to live with it. Like the parents of all those kidnapped girls. Or you can die here.

Murad: What are you telling me?

Bryan Mills: What I'm saying is: if you give me your word, I will throw down this gun and simply walk away.

Murad: Why?

Bryan Mills: Because I am tired of it all.

Heh. Murad can't say he wasn't given an out! Send in the sons!

Films that don't need or can't realistically accommodate a sequel are hashed out all the time, and Taken is no exception. The film reinvented Liam Neeson as a late-in-life action hero (despite having a few successful action films earlier in his career) and was a surprise hit at the box office thanks to its neutered PG-13 rating. A harder cut surfaced on Blu-ray, and the famous monologue of Neeson threatening the kidnappers on the phone entered pop culture, giving the studio hope that a sequel would do big business. The gamble worked, and the sequel took more money than the first. Is it any good? I expected the worst, but I actually prefer this movie to the first.

Made four years later, but set unspecified years later, Bryan Mills and infantile daughter Kim are still getting over their disastrous trip to Paris (where you are guaranteed to to be kidnapped and sold into sexual slavery, so don't even think about it). Former-bitch former-wife Lenore is now back in love with Bryan and surprises him on his last day of a Istanbul assignment by showing up at the hotel. New trip, new disaster. Will the Mills family ever learn to stay at home in America where nothing ever bad ever happened to anyone?

The daddy of the evil kidnapper in the first movie has somehow managed to find Mills and has an army of lowlifes (all of them dressing in dirty 1980s clothes that seemed to have washed-up in a lost container on a Yugoslavian beach some time in 1991) willing to sacrifice their existence for the most arbitrary of reasons (untaxed pay and the boss' approval). Mills and wife are quickly kidnapped and it's up to Kim to rescue them and let him loose to kill, kill, kill the evil foreign men.

I found this film to be more exciting and the danger was ramped-up. It lacks the variety of locations of the first movie (almost every scene is set in a dark alley), and there are some ludicrous plot contrivances (Mills' CIA pals fixing everything with a phonecall or the fact that Jean-Claude still has the same job despite his massive corruption being exposed) but it moves fast enough to make it a non-issue. The action is hard-hitting and Neeson is still a force to be reckoned with as he effortlessly dominates the movie with his presence.

The Blu-ray looks great in 2.40:1 1080p. The movie was shot in a strange combination of Super35 and anamorphic Panavision with lots of high brightness and contrast. Not amazing photography, but it looks nice. The DTS HD-MA sound has some good punchy effects during the action scenes. A bunch of decent extras are included.

I asked myself how could they make a sequel to a film that seemed to be an open and shut affair.  Doesn't Liam Neeson have the integrity not to appear in a cynical exercise even if it is a followup to his biggest hit?  The answer is to have his character taken and will his kidnappers regret the day they messed with Liam.  This film moves at such a razor sharp clip that there really isn't any time to ask questions.  "Taken 2" is a complete adrenaline rush of a movie that doesn't take itself seriously so don't look at it too closely.  For instance why do the Turk officials let Liam leave the country after he dispatches a few dozen Albanians in his wake? Why does the American Embassy release him after he barrels through their roadblock putting a few dozen bullet holes in his vehicle?  I told you to stop asking too many questions!  It's only a movie!

The one man demolition machine that is Brian Mills is at it again: killing people with impunity; this time on the streets of Istanbul. Basically, the family patriarch back in the old country, Albania, finishes burying what remains of the scumbags Brian wiped out in Paris, and vows revenge. He seems to be some kind of mafia godfather who has the usual connections in high places. He quickly finds Brian's location, on a long weekend with `Lenny', his ex-wife and Kim, his once airheaded daughter, in Istanbul, where Brian's just finished protecting the family of some uber rich oil sheik or similar, and starts off to find him with a second cohort of equally nasty scumbags in tow.

Having bribed his way through typically corrupt officials high and low the patriarch sets up camp in what looks like a deserted and run down Istanbul apartment. The apartment block itself looked to be in a very similar part of town to that which both Tom Cruise, in Night and Day, and Clive Owen, in the International, visited. Obviously, the roof tops of old Istanbul provide a good location in which to shoot the odd roof top set piece.

Anyway, having located his prey said patriarch and minions duly `take' Brian and Lenny, in order to fulfil his and the film's mission and truss them up with chains and such like in what looks like the apartment block's basement. Then, being conveniently incompetent, leave them alone with a conveniently incompetent sleepy headed scumbag guard outside. Kim, who, during the film's opening, had received a driving lesson from Brian back in LA, has managed to avoid being captured, by stealing a taxi, and also manages to retrieve Brian's mini arsenal of assault weapons. Brian gives her instructions - yeh, they are able to communicate; I won't say how - and sets about enabling Brian to let her home in on his exact location!

Kim duly retrieves Brian and, now performing like a seasoned rally driver, picks him up at the start of the obligatory car chase through the old streets and alley ways of Istanbul.

Obviously, I can't say how this all turns out but I'm sure you can guess! It's nowhere nearly as good as Brian's first outing and does contain a similar number of sizeable plot holes but does provide some action-packed entertainment, albeit a bit too predictably and we do get to see the rooftops of Istanbul once more!

Here's looking forward to Taken 3 the inevitability of which is set up quite nicely at the end!

I have not been able to get to the theater for taken two and after seeing the Blu-ray with theatrical version, unrated version, and an alternate version, I'm kind of glad that I did not get to see the theatrical version first. The unrated cut in taken 2 is again living proof that the unrated version is the gold standard; I've yet to see any exception to that rule. As the basic blurb on the film synopsis indicates, the turnaround is that the parents get taken. The big difference in approximately the latter third of the film is that it takes an entirely different ambit to the theatrical cut (and I can honestly say that I can't see why they did the theatrical cut the way they did, but there is enough in the film extras if you to make up your own mind). Without giving too much away, they might have called this taken 2; the revenge: however it's more of a vendetta type of situation and I like the way the film has a fairly good prcis of the characters (on both sides) so you can see who has what motivation, and who were the ones that you are going to side with (obviously you are meant to side with Bryan Mills and his family). If you liked TAKEN ONE As Well as  Liam's film UNKNOWN, then I think you will really like the action, adventure, and exploration of a great deal of motivation in the agents.
 There is an alternative ending they supplied, which gives a radical change to the general feel of the film: it's about 25 minutes of fully complete material and has a radically different run in the motivation and action to the extent that you might even be able to get three films out of the entire material. There are five major deleted scenes in the extras, of which the foot chase is the longest and actually provides a lot of intriguing background, in my view. In one of two bonus materials there is a small discussion with Liam Neeson and it really gets into his motivation in the film (not necessarily his character's) as well as the way he works and what he likes about films; it's very enlightening. The final neat bonus is an in-depth animatic of the black ops box (the silver case he takes everywhere) and it is fairly obvious that is very well thought out. Overall, I was not sure if I was going to enjoy this film, due to a lot of negative reviews, but after watching the original TAKEN in saying the somewhat more thoughtful film UNKNOWN (which is based on a book, a spy thriller) I was willing to give TAKEN 2 a try, and I'm glad I did. It's a whacking great ride and loads of fun.

Liam Neeson delivers his promise of great action drama in "Taken 2".  He brings forth a character that is larger than life itself, but makes that fable believable, even if it is only in the movie.  The action scenes and the ability of Neeson to deliver it rates the movie 5-Stars in my book.  Liam Neeson is proving that he is a powerhouse star of the Action Dramas, and anything he does will be a big seller at the boxoffice. In Taken 2, he resurrects his character as an ex-CIA field agent that has a seemingly unending well of resources from which to draw whatever is needed at the time.
I'd recommend this movie to anyone who likes action drama, who likes very good acting abilities mixed in equal parts to pull it off in a winning movie!

I thought the movie was pretty good until they caught Liam Neeson (Bryan) and Famke (Lenore) or Lennie as he called her. So Murad and his men capture Bryan and Lennie and instead of killing them for the revenge of him killing his son he hooks him up to some kind of pipe and scratch his ex-wife and turn her upside down to bleed out.  Like they don't know Bryan can get out any situation by now? His daughter was great when she was determined to help her parents and I felt like she had her father's courage. And the way he told her to find him was brilliant.  But when Bryan and his daughter finally got away and went to the Embassy and he came back to find Lenore his ex-wife laying in some dark corner barely breathing, not once, but TWICE at two different times, I could not take the movie seriously anymore.  Also when the "bad guys" were dragging her around, trying to escape and hide her, she kept making the same grunting noises GRUNTING "No, Let me go" instead of screaming loudly so her husband could follow her screams and find her. She should know by now that her ex-husband would have surely been looking for her. I would have screamed Bryan help!!! Follow my voice!!! She was also a terrible actress, all she knew how to do was lay there on the floor and act like she wasn't breathing and when Bryan found her TWICE, she started breathing again.  Really? Did she have sleep apnea?  I DID like the end though, when Bryan gave Murad a choice to live or die, and left him the gun.  And when Murad chose to use the gun, he killed him, but didn't really want to.  But he obviously thought ahead of time and took the bullet out of the gun knowing that if he left him the gun he just might try to use it on him.  But the ex-wife, no wonder he divorced her. ha ha  It was also the directors fault for not making her more believable too.

"Taken" was, I believe the first attempt to transform Liam Neeson into a macho action hero, and I suppose it succeeded, but it also transformed him into a truly dull person. The first film was ham-handed, unbelievable, and also pretty unappetizing,
with its "white-slavery" plot underpinning. But, as with anything Luc-Besson-related, it's all about the kinetic action.  And that's fine, if the director brings something to it. He doesn't, and the mawkish Hallmark family stuff just dumbs it down further.
  "Taken 2" concerns itself even less with plot... it's just a relentless revenge tale, also clumsily directed.  In terms of believability, it makes any "Die Hard" movie look like a documentary.  I realize these movies are not about realism at all, but the car-
chase scene, where the daughter (who failed her driving test 3 times) goes all Steve McQueen on the tiny twisty Istanbul streets, is ridiculous, and if the director was attempting to be ironic, he failed miserably.
  I think the worst thing, aside from the fact that no one in the film is at all likeable or remotely interesting, the film is totally devoid of humor. Suspense, thrills and humor CAN co-exist.  (witness: "Die Hard"....the first one only!!)
  I DID actually watch both movies, got 'em from my library.  They were good for practicing bass guitar, not much to think about, bouncy, relentless soundtrack. So, really, just an aerobics video.
  Other than that, you could do MUCH better. So could Liam. But I guess at this point he's just collecting paychecks.

somewhat on the shortish side (1:30), but Liam Neeson is up to his same expert, demolitions self when the same crazed Albanian hoodlums who he had a run-in w/ in the 1st flick come after him for revenge, and he's w/ his family in Istanbul. Love the setting! Have always been fascinated by the Byzantine, and later, Ottoman empires and this, their respective capital city. I would dearly love to see this character of Neeson's (Mr. Mills) teamed up in a future James Bond movie, w/ Mills taking the place of Felix Leiter. There would be nothing left!

Crammed full of relentless, nonstop action, even more so than the first installment, "Taken 2" is loads of fun, with excellent direction by Luc Besson, and Liam Neeson once again in top fighting shape.  The Albanians whose sons were murdered by Leeson in "Taken" are out for revenge, and they corner Leeson and his family in Istanbul. What follows are wild blazing car chases through narrow streets and bazaars, with car-to-car shootouts, pileups and crashes, countless well-choreographed karate chop-chop martial arts battles between Neeson and the thugs, pop-pop shootings, stabbings and garrotings, and torture scenes.  It is extremely formulaic, very much a cutout of the original, but you can't help cheering for Neeson when he commands his daughter -- "stay focused" -- and proceeds to kick, shoot and flail his way through legions of surly-looking Albanian thugs, emerging remarkably unblemished.  Apparently the chief thug still has a couple of sons unaccounted for, which leaves the door open for a sequel.  I say, go for it.  Excellent, absolutely first-rate production values and nice performances by all.

Even though I enjoyed watching Taken 2 tonight, the truth is it's *extremely* similar to the first Taken.  Only because I'm such a huge fan of high octane action films such as this one will I give in and award the movie 4 stars.  It's realistically more like a 3-star film.  Anyway it stars the always talented Liam Neeson doing exactly what he did in the first Taken- chasing bad guys around with guns and his fists, and specifically and strategically planning the best ways to instruct his daughter to avoid being captured by the kidnappers.  Liam's daughter and wife play larger roles in the storyline this time around (at least the daughter does- the wife is basically spending her time being a helpless captured victim).

I have to be honest.  Even though Liam coming up with these carefully planned directions to either guide his daughter to safety or help him escape where he's being held/captured, I have to laugh at how unrealistically sharp and skilled he is at his technique.  It's unintentionally really funny to me how he never misses a beat when explaining what to do and where to go.  I wasn't laughing in the first movie when Liam did the same thing perhaps due to his character being really believable and just plain good, but now it seems really funny for some reason.  Probably means Taken wasn't meant to have a sequel and segments such as these weren't meant to occur ever again.  That way we could preserve the greatness of the original Taken and recognize it as one of Liam's highest achievements as an actor.  The sequel kind of ruins what made the first one so great.

What seems particularly odd about Taken 2 however, is all the storyline segments concerning Liam's daughter.  She doesn't want to drive, she doesn't have the confidence to pass her driving test, and she doesn't believe she's good enough at parellel parking, however all these issues magically go away just as soon as she's forced to speed away from the gun-carrying kidnappers.  Suddenly her driving abilities improve dramatically (with a couple exceptions).  It's odd writing.  It's almost like her driving problems never should have been included in the script and were only included because the writers couldn't think of another way to make her character memorable.  Also, it's hilarious that she doesn't hesitate to pull pins from grenades and toss them across the street (a fairly clever piece of writing here, though probably not realistic but I could be wrong- you'll see why when you watch the movie).  Basically Liam is using the sound and the amount of seconds that passes after the grenade explosion to figure out where he's being captured.  His daughter is able execute these instructions without feeling any fear which is odd.

This movie is also a victim of camera jerking during the action scenes, which means when Liam is running around beating people up, we don't really see it- all we see is the camera jerking all over the place.  I can't recall if the originl was guilty of this same noticeable flaw.  I strongly dislike when movies ruin the action scenes with quick camera movements.  Also the writing in several spots is incredibly cliched.  Of *course* Liam doesn't approve of his daughter's new boyfriend, and the boyfriend acts exactly as you'd expect- very confident, willing to shake hands, willing to present himself as a perfect gentlement.  Meh.  The original Taken was too good to resort to this kind of boring and obvious writing.  I'd expect the same out of the sequel.

Overall, Taken is a highly exaggerated but ultimately disappointing sequel.  I really should give it 3 stars but... I can't, because it was entertaining.  Sigh, haha.

This sequel to "Taken" is more of the same, the first film was so believable & was a real no holds barred suspense thriller about a former CIA operative who knows his way around the world & gets the guys who take his daughter for the purpose of white slavery, he kills many of them in his quest to find her, & rescues her at the end, this follow-up had a good premise, with some family members of the people he killed in the first film wanting revenge, but I feel they really should have had the bad guys coming to Los Angeles to get their revenge rather than have another overseas mishap, some years have passed since the first film's events, & Liam Neeson once again commands the screen as a over protective father, there are some highlights such as him & his ex-wife(Famke Jansen) sort of re-connecting, but then he has a overseas assignment where he is protecting a world leader, once the job is done his ex-wife & daughter make a surprise appearance, this is where you really have to suspend belief, why would a daughter who was kidnapped want to take another overseas trip?, why would her mother want to even take her overseas after what happened in the first film, & why would Neeson even be happy they were there?...knowing the dangers all around them, what follows is more of the same as Neeson & Jansen are taken this time, & the daughter (Maggie Grace) has to help her parents, again there is so much suspension of disbelief here, when what they should have done is have the bad guys come to L.A. & Neeson fight them there, that would have been more believable, this like many sequels suffers from sheer laziness on the part of the filmakers who know they have an audience & do nothing different, this one has its share of action, but it could have been sooo much better!!...& it wasn't.....this one is a mixed bag for me.

It is set in Istanbul and makes one grateful not to be there. There is a lot of shooting, fighting, and chases and offers an adequate action film for those who enjoy such things.

I am a fan of Liam Neeson and enjoy action movies in general. However, I expect the story of the action movie to be developed in a reasonable manner on top of showing the bravery and physical fights. Unfortunately, this was not the case with this movie as I will explain in what follows. First, the director/film-writer does not seem to be familiar with the city where the story is supposedly happening, i.e. Istanbul (a city in a country named Turkey). Or he is intentionally showing it extremely ugly which I hope is not the case. Having been to Istanbul at least twice myself, I can tell you that Istanbul is very European looking with a lot of people dressing in a Western style. The second and main reason why I was disappointed with this movie was because the story was so cheesy and the dialogues were so phony. As if the director did not bother developing the plot so the viewer would feel the smoothness in the flow of the story and find the events reasonably natural. I just do not understand, for example, why one should drag the boyfriend into the movie when there is no significant role? Or in the last action seen, when did Liam Neeson take out the bullet before the criminal guy get the hand gun?

In the end, why should we drag people's religion into the movie by showing the Muslim prayer in the opening scene and broadcasting the Adhan (Islamic call to prayer) several time in the movie as if all of them are evil? After all, Turkey is a secular country with close ties to the West in general and USA specifically. I do not think it is a good idea to instigate hatred by stereotyping.

Taken 2 was a very rehashed plot point which is why it wasn't the greatest sequel I could have experienced. That being said, I LOVED the way Liam Neeson handled the material and, if you watch it right after part one, it feels like the natural progression of the story and you can gain a whole new appreciation for this film. Famke Janssen is painfully hot and I love that they set up her return to him, which was my only grip about part one. He proved he was right and fought a One-Man-War to get his daughter back, comes home injured and the wife still goes with the rich idiot at the end of one. WTF! But beyond the similar plot from one, this is a solid sequel and can't wait for part 3.

Unfortunately this sequel to the excellent "Taken" (2008) provides little new and is certainly inferior to the original.  In this Olivier Megaton directed money grab, Liam Neeson remains effective as a former government secret agent.  In the original, he goes after Albanian goons involved in the sex trade.  They made the mistake of kidnapping Bryan Mill's (Neeson) teen age daughter Kim (Maggie Grace) which put Bryan in full on battle mode where he is able to use "his special skills."  This time, Kim's is still a teenager trying to pass her driver's license exam after a couple failures.

As an aside, I'm a big fan of the TV show "Californication" and 29 year old Maggie Grace has her own "special skills" in her role as a rock `n roll groupie in the recent season.  For her next role maybe she can play a high school student on "Glee."  Anyway, even if Kim can't parallel park, she can sure drive the hell out of a Mercedes cab, complete with a manual transmission.  Hard to focus on the plot, or lack thereof.

Bryan is on assignment in Turkey and the Albanian head of the family, Murad Krasniqi (reliable Rade Serbedzija), is out for revenge.  He and his henchman travel to Istanbul and get a bonus in that Kim and Bryan's ex-wife Lenore (Famke Janssen) meet him there.  This time Lenore and Bryan are kidnapped and Kim must play a key role in getting them rescued.  There's nothing overly offensive except the script, especially some of the dialog.  Like "Kim, drive faster" or "Kim, go go go" and of course Kim freaking out.  There was no need to make this more-of-the-same movie except for box office receipts of course.

Taken 1 is one of my favorite movies, so I was excited when I heard that Taken 2 was coming out. Taken 2 didn't have as well written dialogue or as many thrills as the first Taken, but Taken 2 was still good. The only thing that really bothered me about this movie was the directing. The director of this movie used a kinetic style of directing, which makes it hard to see all of the action.....the shaking of the camera was really annoying, as it is with all movies that use it. I still liked this movie, but Taken 1 was A LOT better.

Another intense installment of the Mills' family misfortunes.

Criticisms that the team behind 'Taken', including one of my favorite director/producers Luc Besson, are repeating themselves is fair.

However, and this is important, that's like criticizing a home run because the batter only just made it over the wall.

The fact that the ball went over at all is a blessed near-miracle nowadays and we should be grateful; especially in the US market where facile, plastic, and pathetic are commonplace. In all honesty, I haven't seen such a dearth of weak sorry excuses for filmmaking since the late 70s-thru-mid 80s, where schlock was king. This is a new Dark Age for many cinephiles. The digital revolution allowing ill-trained, ill-equipped, lowest common denominators access to the technical and commercial inroads that were previously closed off, disgorging a stunning plethora of cinematic garbage.

So remember that when considering formula films. What they lack in creativity, they more than make up for in pure adrenaline enjoyment.

As before, retired field agent Bryan Mills is placed in the position of having to defend his family from a host of nogoodniks. However, in a twist, he finds himself as the primary target.

Having righteously killed his daughter's kidnappers, and as family is the theme of the franchise, what he had forgotten was that those worthless turds had family too. Angry families. Gangster families.

Despite the fact that Marco, a.k.a. Mr. "Good Luck", was a sincere bleeping scumbag who kidnapped young women, violently raped and abused them, then dumped them into slave pits to suffer a horrific and sickening life of drug induced prostitution and an anonymous garbage dump of a grave - his father doesn't care what his p.o.s. of a son did, only that it was his son that was killed. And he wants his pound of flesh. Literally.

The obvious failing, and one that did slightly annoy, was the plot avoidance of Revenge Rule No. 1: You can never go back.

Once you burn a bridge, especially when it's filled with people, that's gone forever. You can never return to where that bridge once stood. But what do the Mills do? Seriously, Europe should've been dead to them. Even an English or Irish trip would've been risky. The continent? Forget it. There are at least three other global land masses one can explore over one's lifetime. Lotta room in the world not to have to repeatedly bump into people. Especially people who detest and hate you.

Other than that minor complaint, 'Two' was a kickass epinephrine rush!

Very solid four.

Personal Note:

- I'm a huge fan of Leland Orser and would love to see a film just about his character. The man shares the technical, political and badass intelligence background as the main character, Bryan Mills, but seems infinitely more hooked into the system. Two pennies: His backstory has a ton of potential.

Taken 2 suffers from the typical movie sequel clich, the second one is not as good as the first.  Both movies followed exactly the same formula: villain kidnaps family of the hero, car chases ensue, body count mounts, hero kills head honcho villain in a climatic confrontation, hero and family live happily ever after.

But while Taken was a fantastic movie and had me on the edge of my seat the whole time, Taken 2 was kinda ho-hum.  I had two big issues with the plot:  1) The whole kidnapping, chase, and rescue scenario was so far-fetched  that it was almost laughable.  2) The villain was made to look too "human".  In the first scene of Take 2 the villain (a gray-haired old man) is shown burying his son and other family members and vowing revenge against his son's killer.  In a different movie this story line would have made this man the hero.  This setup just made the old man look like less of an evil psychopath (like the villain in the first movie) and more like a grieving father bent on revenge.

The things that saved this movie were the great acting and the beautiful location.
This sequel just didn't have the passion and drive nor logic of the first. But with that said it was entertaining and a fun watch.
