I can overlook an occassional bit of acting or cinematogrophy or development in the story line that I feel requires me to not take it too seriously or look too deeply into it for the sake of enjoying the film, but there has to be a balance to this; the product has to eventually, in some way, justify itself as being worthy of the time.  This movie had me shaking my head and rolling my eyes so often I felt I was as unbalanced as the film halfway through it.  I personally feel this to be the weakest effort of Neeson, an opinion, I suppose, made all the easier to come to for the fact he seems completely incapable of fulfilling the requirements of the character.  A question: how do you create the illusion that a person is more capable and deft in hand-to-hand combat vs. 7 thugs all the while remaining completely stationary and as slow as Kim Kardashian's acumen? You edit the living crap out of a 3 minute fight scene with hundreds and hundred of stop and go cuts after every single dodge, punch, or lunge. Are you kidding me?? It's not worth the time going into all the bits about throwing hand grenades into the streets or plowing a car through the embassy gates and being apparently blessed with a contingent of Marines who suddenly forgot how to pull the triggers on their standard issues in accordance with standard protocol (which is where I quit watching).  All in all, absolutely one of the worst films I have watched in quite...a long long long time.

However, it's still good.  It took a lot to convince me of Liam Neeson's legitimacy as an action-adventure star.  The first Taken did that.  This sequel has as much action but it's not quite as believeable as the first one.  Don't get me wrong, though.  I thoroughly enjoyed it.

The first Taken really catapulted Liam Neeson in an unexpected genre: the action super hero. It was fresh, original and exciting. That was in large part to Neeson himself, who is so unassuming as ex-CIA Agent Bryan Mills; but he is such a talented Actor and the characterization was done so well without doing too much in the first film. So when Taken 2 came out, I was really excited. However, with the good, there is the bad. *Spoilers ahead* GOOD: Neeson is as awesome as ever. More importantly, he continues to be believable and virtually carries the whole film with some help of Maggie Grace, aka, Kim Mills. The whole cast was back, from the ex-wife to his group of spy friends to the French Inspector, even if briefly for most. The plot had lots of potential with the Albanian family of the men Mills killed, coming after the Mills family for revenge. The action is good, fast-pace and typical Luc Besson, ala Transporter. BAD: Pretty much everything else. I don't mind repetition when done right. However, the screenplay, as a whole, is a complete bust and tries waaaaay to hard to recapture the energy and quiet intelligence of the first Taken. For one, it nearly mimics the first movie in every respect, including dialogue, which got cringeworthy. It is also set just months after Kim's rescue, which didn't make any sense since the actress was 29 at the time and didn't look like a high school girl about to get her driver's license. The characterization of the ex-wife, Lenore, is the second worst in the movie, but Famke Janssen did her best but it wasn't good enough to compete with Neeson or even Grace. The overall performance is forced, stilted and cliched. The worst characterization of the story is Murad, the Albanian leader who kidnaps the MIlls and is the father of one of the slain kidnappers who first kidnapped Kim. The writers did poorly in developing a truly evil counterpart to Mills. He is not this scary evil villain that you're glad the good guy disposes of accordingly. He was not even close to Mills stature and to not have a villain who is worthy and equal to Mills was just pathetic and for me, weakens the movie. Ugh, the dialogue; it got distracting and was horrendous. Ignore it to truly enjoy the movie. Besson (The Professional,La Femme Nikita), who is one of my favorite directors, is not the best writer; he should have stuck to directing this film himself which is something he does best and this movie could have used it. The cast does its best with what it was given but even they seemed to know how bad it was throughout the film. Again, the overall CONCEPT of the plot held promise but it quickly unraveled to the predictable and nonsensical. Thankfully, the action is what propels the film, as well as Neeson's electric performance.
Like action movies and this was good in that sense but having enjoyed the newness of Taken maybe I wanted more surprise.  Good though and entertaining for a night in if you like action films....I do.

TAKEN released in 2008 was a tightly woven thriller that boosted Liam Neeson's already burgeoning career: he was a killer's killer and managed to garner acclaim from critics and audiences alike.  Now we have a sequel (and there may be more, as the end of the film suggests) that just isn't up to the same standard as the original, but for those who saw Part 1, then Part 2 will likely not disappoint.

The film opens in Albania where the old father Murad Krasniqi (Rade Serbedzija) is burying his son and some villagers killed by Bryan Mills (Liam Neeson) and he vows revenge. Switch to Los Angles where we see Bryan and his ex-wife Lenore (Famke Janssen), who is recuperating from her second divorce, and their daughter Kim (Maggie Grace) who is entering her first relationship with Jamie (a promising Luke Grimes) arguing over priorities.  Bryan still loves Kim and Lenore and when Lenore tearfully confesses her frustration that her plans to take Kim to China to regroup emotionally have fallen through, Bryan announces he has a job in Istanbul, Turkey - 3 days worth - and invites them to join him after his job is complete.
But of course in Istanbul Bryan's mission involves offing all the people from the Albanian crew and when Lenore and Kim arrive the family is re-bonded until Murad directs that all three be captured and killed. From there it is the predictable cat and mouse games of capture/escape/killing by every means possible/ car chases action and the few who are left in the end make a pact of sorts...and more need not be said.

Oliver Megaton directs a screenplay by Luc Besson and Robert Mark Kamen. One of the glories of the film is the opportunity to see the many sites of Istanbul. This is not a bad film at all - it is just not up to the standard of the original even thought he players are the same.  Grady Harp, April 13

Thanks to the first film of the TAKEN series, under the auspices of 20th Century Fox, Liam Neeson as butt-kicking ex-spy Bryan Mills has successfully rebranded himself as one of the elder statesman of action cinema, now able almost to be spoken in the same sentence as names like Willis or Stallone. Then after that came a series that should have pushed the point home that he didn't belong there, with films like THE A-TEAM and UNKNOWN, which were both terrifically bad films. Unfortunately, he reteamed with A-TEAM director Joe Carnahan for THE GREY, an existential survival thriller that was well-received amongst fans and not unliked by critics. So, the Neeson Express was still rolling, and Fox, never knowing when to let a good idea lie (see the ALIEN, PREDATOR or DIE HARD series for evidence of this), decided to try to create a franchise out of what could only really succeed as a one-off. This led us to TAKEN 2, and what is one of the most boring, most unentertaining and really, one of the stupidest films of the year.

Basically, the film revolves around Mills' recently-divorced ex-wife Lenore (Famke Janssen, reprising her role) and daughter Kim (Maggie Grace, also reprising her ageless role) surprising him in Istanbul very shortly after he's concluded his protection service there. At the same time, the father (the wasted character actor Rade Serbedzija) of the "Good Luck" Albanian who Mills let fry in the chair from the first film, has sworn vengeance on Mills and his family. But instead of the daughter being taken, it's him and his wife. And Kim is the only one that can assist her father. And through a series of increasingly implausible scenarios, Mills takes the bad guys on to save his ex-wife.

I know that some people felt that there could never be a sequel to a film like DIE HARD because of how singular that film felt. Four sequels later, they're still expanding the idea to a fault. Well, TAKEN, because of its specific plot (kidnapped daughter), can really only work once, and as evidenced by this film, it's true. Bryan Mills, while being a badass, is little else. His motivations to save the wife of his ex-wife, who seems very keen on rekindling their relationship after her latest marriage ends, seem much weaker than a father protecting his daughter, and his pursuit of their assailants seem much more languid and rote. This is obviously a film that is going to hold no surprises, and to be honest, that should be enough. But the direction by French-director-with-the-greatest-action-film-director-name-ever, Olivier Megaton (TRANSPORTER 3, COLOMBIANA) is, similarly to his previous work, pretty uninspired and has no real excitement or vitality to it. Even the "final fight sequence" is dull and unimpressive. Neeson is just going through the motions here. I appreciate that actors are working people, and that they need to get some change in their pockets, but Neeson must have turned down better films than this. Janssen just exists to look nearly unconscious through most of the film, and Grace, who I really loved on LOST, and thought she was a lot of fun in the film LOCKOUT, has an expanded role here, but still makes not much of an impression. Plus, how old is she supposed to be? In LOST, she seemed to be in her early to mid-twenties, but in these films, she seems to be in her teens, and it really doesn't work.

I'm going to perhaps spoil something here, so you might want to not continue reading if you don't want to know more about the most idiotic point of the film. The film opens with Bryan looks to give his daughter driving lessons since she keeps flunking the parallel parking part. Of course, this means that a certain part of the film will require her to drive. When we get to this film's been-done-a-thousand-times-before car chase, she is inexplicably behind the wheel and instead of there being any beats where she is driving the car poorly, or is freaking out because she can't get the car in gear, she is driving this car like Jason Bourne on a bottle of No-Doz. She is doing things with a six-speed manual transmission that master stunt drivers would be envious of. And the finale of this chase scene culminates with Bryan instructing his daughter to drive DIRECTLY THROUGH the gates of the American Embassy without stopping, assuring that 50-caliber machine guns and other weapons begin firing at the car. And you know what? That's not even the stupidest part of the scene. It's when Bryan makes a call to one of his stateside spy buddies that puts an ignominous cap on this frighteningly moronic scene.

If I didn't think that TAKEN 2 was a bad idea before I saw it, I can guarantee to you now that it's a way of wasting valuable time that you will never get back. Skip it.

However, I gave this movie only 3 stars because of its jumpy and inconsistent scenes. It didn't flow as well as the first one. Is it the directing, editing, both?  For example, when his daughter drops the gun down the roof vent I didn't see her drop extra cartridges with it and yet after he empties the gun on the bad guys then reloads and continues blasting away. Its 'amazing' how he can avoid a zillion machine gun bullets and yet drops a guy with one shot. Even Rambo got hit once in a while. Also there were parts in the movie where it was difficult to understand what they were saying even when we turned the volume up. Oh well, we still enjoyed the movie and hopefully the next sequel will improve on this one. According to the revengeful father, he had 2 other sons who will surface for sure and seek more revenge. How can there not be another sequel?

I saw it in the local DVD rental and was attracted to it the way one is attracted to the scene of an accident. Could it be any worse than its predecessor? The short answer is, yes. A plot of staggering weakness and sublime silliness, varying wildly between maudlin sloppiness and utter mayhem, with holes sufficiently large to swallow an entire depot of London buses, laughable acting and the consumption of more ammunition than was used on D-Day. Now if you like fairy stories of the good guys coming out on top with barely a scratch and having massacred an entire battalion of nasties, then this is for you, but otherwise I'd recommend that you avoid.

The worrying thing is that there is left hanging in the plot the possibility of a "Taken 3"... Given the enthusiasm of other reviewers, this could be a done deal.

Given this is the 1,107th review here, I'll keep it short and sweet because "there's no time!"

Really all that is different is we've gone from "Quickly! There's no time!" (thank you Geoff Peterson) to "Listen to me! There's no time!" The Taken series is definitely a bonafide good thrill ride that'll get your heart beating. If you've seen #1 it's more of the same in #2. Setting the movie in Istanbul was genius as well.

The DVD extras are decent. Nice short FX Movies interview with Liam Neeson and an alternate ending that is worth watching just to see how they changed it. I actually think both work well. You can be the judge as I won't spoil it for anyone.

So, what do you get when you give an enormous budget, superstar actors, and no oversight to a pretentious, self-important, ex-graffiti artist turned movie maker, who has no sense of timing, spacial relations, or how to frame a shot?

Well, you get Taken 2. Holy cow, what a mess. Given a different director and a slight re-write this movie would have been fantastic. There was so much there to work with, but the director had no idea what he was doing. My wife and I had to rewind almost every other scene because you couldn't tell where people were, what they were doing, or how they did it. The climax of the movie looked like Liam Neeson killed a guy by gently shoving his face. What?! After two rewinds we FINALLY saw that he had been impaled on something that was barely in the frame and you can't see until you look at it very carefully. We love action movies and we don't need to be spoon fed a narrative, but it REALLY helps when the shots actually show you what the heck is going on.

And on that note, hey, Oliver "Megaton" Fontana! It's called "Shaky" cam, not "Donkey With Restless Leg Syndrome Is Kicking the Camera" cam. And quick zooms don't work if that's all you do for two hours and the framing NEVER focuses on the subjects. Seriously, this guy would start already partially zoomed in to frame a character and then he would quick zoom so fast that the camera couldn't find the actor for 3-4 seconds, all the while we're looking at a car bumper or a blank wall. And when your shots only LAST 4 seconds max, that's an eternity of time in which we can't watch a movie because this guy obviously doesn't know how photography works. I did a count with about 30 minutes to go in the movie and I gave up after 10 minutes because there was exactly ONE scene in which he kept a shot going for longer than 3 seconds. Most of the shots only lasted half a second and then we're slammed into another angle, camera gyrating wildly, and then before we can focus, WHACK, we're in yet another shot. It's called pacing, "Megaton". This guy shouldn't be hired to do anything other than music videos or McDonalds ads. Then his complete lack of a clue wouldn't be as noticeable. This isn't a style, it's a desperate bid to use a camera technique to hide incompetence.

A quick word about the director's name. He calls himself Oliver Megaton. His real name is Oliver Fontana. If you have the arrogance to name yourself after a measurement for explosive force, then at least be sure you have the skill to back that mess up. This guy shouldn't call himself "Megaton". I've popped balloons that have more punch than his films.

There is a nice joke going 'round out there about Liam Neeson: "I trained Obi-Wan Kinobi, I killed the White Witch of Narnia, I trained Batman, and you still want to kidnap my daughter?"  Let that sink in...
  Pretty good eh?  Taken 2 puts a different spin on the story, years after he rescues his daughter from human traffickers Neeson's character, Brian, is still just as anal as ever, but if you're seen the first one you know it's for good reasons.  This time the father of one of the kidnappers from the first movie (who doesn't care that his son was an international criminal, criminal or not that was his son) creates a plot to take vengeance of Brian and his entire family while they are vacationing overseas.  If you liked the first one, you'll love the character evolution of the second one.  I don't want to say anymore, I'll spoil it so, Thanks for reading and have a nice day!

Hollywood love sequels.  Most are not as good as the original.  While that is true, here, it is still a very good action/adventure movie that keeps you engaged.  The acting is good, and while the direction is not quite up to that of the first movie, the movie still works as intended  The storyline is basically the families of those killed in the first movie, want revenge in this one.  The locations used are interesting.

There is one blunder that doesn't detract from the movie, but whoever wrote the script, should have known better.  There is no US Embassy in Istanbul.  The US Embassy to Turkey is in Ankara, the country's capital.

If you rated the original as a 10(being fantastic), this would easily be a 6 or 7.  The acting was wonderful(Neeson turning in another stellar performance), and his co-stars were also great.  The bad guys were especially creepy, easily being as bad as the monsters in Taken.  Out of the more than 90 minutes of this movie, I'd say there was possibly 5 minutes where you weren't glued to your chair waiting for the next scene.  I would DEFINITELY say that you should rent or purchase this movie.  You won't regret spending the money.

"Taken 2" is half just a fun action movie (if this is your idea of fun) and half an attempt at understanding CIA Nietzschean Superman -one dude anti kidnapping-killing machine Bryan Mills.  Keep in mind that in the first Taken--which possessed an eerie mood that made it stand out, along with Liam Neeson's sinister bravado--Bryan Mills rescued his daughter from Albanian kidnappers in less than 72 hours and singlehandedly dismantled the Albanian mob in about half an hour.

Not entirely so, it would seem.  In a slightly absurd plot device, Mills' daughter Kim (Maggie Grace, who is 30 and continues to play adolescents convincingly) and wife Lenore (Famke Jannsen) follow him to Istanbul, overwhelmed by enthusiasm because Kim has just learned to drive.

Well, as you might guess, they are "Taken".  An Albanian mob boss is determined to avenge the deaths of his young sons whom Mills killed in an attempt to get his daughter back.  Though his sons were scum, the mob boss does sort of seem sympathetic at times, chaining up Mills and confronting him with his own, well, misdeeds.  "You connected my son Markos to an electrical current until his heart burst.  You killed these men like they were so many nothings."  Mills knows why he did what he did, but you get the impression he's a bit more mellow by the end of the film.  Well, after about 300 deaths and car wrecks that Evil Kanevel would not have the remote chance of surviving.  This isn't up to the par of the original film, but if you noticed Bryan Mills, you'll want to see it anyway.

This is the review. You have to focus. Don't let your eyes leave this page. The words on this webpage have the following meaning. Parallel parking's difficulty level is now far greater than the difficulty level of evading multiple Turkish police interceptors in the maze of streets in the centre of Istanbul (not Constantinople).

You have to pull yourself together now, and finish reading this review. As long as your father is there in the passenger seat commanding you in short, staccato word-bursts, you can drive a Mercedes 5-speed taxicab through narrow twisting alleys and never miss a gear. Keep going.

I'll bet you never knew the U.S. Embassy in Istanbul was located at the centre of a maze of twisting streets and narrow alleys. It's turns out that's where the U.S. likes to locate its embassies, at least in majority-Islamic countries: far from the airport, in the midst of the city where there are the tightest, narrowest streets, where you can't see what's up ahead of the motorcade too well, and with lots of irregular architecture on either side; lots of good routes for escorting those important diplomats to and from the airport.

You know, "Taken 2" had my interest, as did the much better first in the "Taken" franchise. But then it got silly. And I started to laugh a lot more than I should've. "Taken 3" should be the story of Kim (Maggie Grace) dating this young Albanian-American guy whose family aren't killers, slavers, or kidnappers (they own a shop that sells designer clothes); that'll be good for some dramatic tension between the boyfriend and the Bryan Mills character. And then Kim and her boyfriend get taken by some vengeance-minded Americans who've decided they've had enough with Albanians kidnapping people all over the world. And then Bryan and Lenore Mills get taken by a group of Albanians who mistake them for the previously mentioned Americans who kidnapped Kim and her boyfriend, whom the Albanians are trying to rescue. And then THOSE Albanians get kidnapped by a group of Chuvash villagers from north of the Volga River. The Chuvash villagers then hire a highly trained group of Faroe Islands natives whose specialty is abduction, to kidnap themSELVES, and the entire story is told backwards, with all the scenes in reverse order. Christopher Nolan will direct.

"Taken 2" is good for what it's supposed to be: a movie with a lot of action. Car action. Gun action. Hand-to-hand combat action.  It's just hard to take any of it seriously. The first one had the advantage of that premise that clearly sells a lot of movies: (deep voice) they %#*!ed with the wrong man. Also, moviegoers seem to take a degree of perverse pleasure in seeing innocence get threatened, as long as those doing the threatening of innocence are horrifyingly punished and killed later on in the film. "Taken 2" it's like... nobody cares if Mr. and Mrs. Mills get kidnapped. They're not innocent, playful ingnues with hearts of gold, facing an horrific fate that would make the strongest person blanch with terror.

But hey, the performers need to take a bow, because they never falter in their honest portrayals of these made-up characters. Their conviction is perfect, even when things get silly. In "Taken 1" Maggie Grace had to create a convincing, true to life persona out of the rawest human emotions (extreme excitement/happiness and extreme terror) and succeeded admirably. In "Taken 2" she plays the clich part of "18 year-old girl in love for the first time" like a real, live person and Not a clich; matured by her ordeals, but still a bit of a romantic and starlet-wannabe. She turns in a better, more varied performance here than she did as the San Fernando Valley clich in "Taken 1."

And can anyone think of anything bad to say about Famke Janssen or Rade Serbedzija? If so, those people had best not come near me, for I have several choice words I would fain share with such people.

And no matter how bad a movie gets, I will not, I will Never diss Admiral Zeus from Planet Krull. The man is a genius. I wish I had even a fraction of this man's genius. Watch the very last scene of "Taken 2" for a bit of this man's infective genius. Thanks, Liam. Now I'm unable to greet friends of that name without almost laughing.

"we shall make him pay for protecting his young innocent dauther from my criminal son.  pack your things mohammed's 1 through 20, let's go avenge akbar!!!!"  mindless entertainment.

I loved "Taken," the original movie starring Liam Neeson. Very much like the "Bourne" series, it was exciting and somewhat plausible. This movie was weak on many levels and stretched logic far beyond reasonable limits. If I was being constantly hunted by foreign terrorists, even in the relative safety of my own U.S. cities, why in the world would I take my wife and daughter to some place like Istanbul? You just know from the minute he suggests such a trip that someone will be kidnapped or killed. How about a ski trip to Colorado instead?

Yes there are some exciting fight scenes, shootouts, and car chases - but even those scenes become boring and ridiculously implausible. A woman has her throat cut and is then hung upside down. She is left like that, dripping copious amounts of blood while gun battles, fights, and car chases take place all over the city. When she is rescued, she is revived in just minutes, has little or no blood on her hair or clothes, and is able to converse and even run along with her rescuer.

Sorry - I love Neeson - but after a while the eastern European terrorists all begin to look alike, talk with the same accent, and even being 20 years younger, can not outfight a man twice their age who has already been wounded, bruised, battered, and tortured for hours. Neeson can do much better than this.

I was really surprised by the first movie when it came out because it was an above average thriller with some great action. The first movie did a great job of setting the stakes so that the viewer felt more involved in the action which allows a certain suspense of disbelief. This film is just plain bad from the acting to the editing and everything in between, as someone who owns the original Taken on Bluray, I had a hard time finishing this one.
But worth watching. Especially if you are a Liam Neeson fan. The scenery in Istanbul is very pretty. Have fun!

The first Taken was better. This was a very shallow plot. The characters are developed just enough to make us think we care about them and then the bad guys go after them. The whole movie is the good guys being terrorized by the bad guys as the good guys shoot everyone in Istanbul. They crash every car in the city too. The daughter's lines were easy for her to remember.  "Dad!"  Leam Neeson's lines are, "listen carefully."

Maybe they are setting her up for something in the future. I probably should have given this a four star rating but the set up was good, good scenery and locations, and it did keep your attention and raise apprehension at the outcome. Edge of your seat type stuff.  I really like Liam in this type of role as an operative. Five stars because it's Liam man!

This movie nearly, but not quite, attains the status of accidental satire. The script is so absolutely dire - based on the classic five-second pitch "hey, what if this time round the parents are the ones who get taken and the kid has to save them?" - that you want everyone to die within the first ten minutes just to get it all over with. Alas, this doesn't happen and so Neeson - a decent actor who deserves much better scripts, roles, and everything else than this - ponderously plods his way through one inept plot device to the next. There's one genuinely accidentally funny line when the Neeson character tells his daughter, who's in an expensive hotel room in downtown Istanbul, via a mini phone "Take a grenade. Remove the pin. Now, throw it somewhere safe."

Aside from that one brief moment, the rest of the movie is so turgid, so absolutely lacking in imagination, pacing, drama, and everything else that it is quite impossible to understand why the crew bothered to show up each day to make the movie - unless the crew were Turkish and didn't speak English and therefore didn't understand just how truly bad this pathetic movie-by-numbers is.

Avoid at all costs unless you're desperately insomniac.

I was looking for a movie to rent today, and I spotted this sequel to a movie I had watched years ago and enjoyed.  Since it still had the lead actor, Liam Neeson, I assumed that it would be a decent sequel.  Usually, it is the ones that re-cast the film that you have to worry about.  I actually had to stop and wonder to myself as to how they would be able to continue the storyline.  I was under the impression that the first movie had cleared up all of the loose ends.

The writer(s) of the sequel chose a tie-in idea that was plausible, despite my initial worries, but the details when it came to translating the idea into a quick introduction scene to the film were very weak.  I found myself unable to suspend disbelief, despite reminding myself that this is Hollywood; it was just that poor of an execution.

My hopes lifted once the movie started proper, and we had dialog from the actors, but it did a slow nosedive through until the end for me.  By the time I had gotten halfway through the movie, I was beginning to lose interest in the specifics of the story.  Thankfully, the action scenes were sufficient to keep me awake, despite being over the top and thus unrealistic.

(Possible spoiler) In my opinion, the worst part of the movie was the car chase scene.  It featured one character driving a car and a second character riding in the passenger seat.  The car was attempting to elude the bad guys and the police who were chasing them through these tiny streets of Istanbul.  The first problem was that the driver did not have a drivers licence because they could not even figure out how to parallel park.  Yet here they were navigating these tiny streets at full throttle, using advanced techniques such as using the emergency brake to power slide and drift around corners?  The second problem was the passenger was yelling the following three things over and over again: Keep low! (they were being shot at), Faster, faster!, Do it!.  He must have repeated the same lines at least five times in the short car chase.  To make things worse, the driver responded to each line with I cant! I cant.  I felt like I was in some kind of demented time warp!

The movie ended with a Hallmark moment straight out of 50s television show endings.  Sappy and cheesy.  To add salt to the wound, the story left open an avenue for a third movie to branch off from, so I wouldnt be surprised to see another sequel in the future.  Sad, but not surprised.

All in all, the movie was not the worst way to spend an hour and a half, but I certainly won't be recommending this one to my friends and family or watching it again in the future.

Taken 2 is a typical sequel that does not match the quality of the original.  Liam Neeson does his choreographed kung pao-fuey well and kills plenty of bad guys again, but the movie fails in other respects.  First, in one scene he and his daughter (with her driving too well for someone still without a driver's license) burst into the courtyard of the US Embassy in Istanbul in a stolen Mercedes taxi seeking refuge from a group of bad guys chasing them.  Apparently in the movie, the embassy has no vehicle barriers and no strong gate, and a taxi can take multiple hits from 50 cal. machine guns fired by a handful of guards and keep going.  Second, after bursting onto the embassy grounds, Maggie Grace's character disappears from almost the rest of the movie only to reappear briefly back in Los Angeles at the end of the movie.  Third, after they burst onto the embassy grounds, Neeson's character is suddenly shown roaming the streets of Istanbul again in search of his wife.  How did he get out of the embassy so quickly even after shooting a Turkish cop during the car chase?  That is not shown.  The story suddenly jumps there.

Taken 2 is a waste of money since several elements of the story are nonsense.  The same care was not taken with the sequel as with the original.  Everyone involved in the movie seems to have shown up to simply collect a paycheck.  Liam Neeson does not even say his trademark line as well as in the original.

I truly enjoyed the first "Taken".  I am a big fan of Liam Neeson, and I loved seeing him mix it up with the "baddies" in the first film.  I was perfectly content to overlook the fact that not one of about a gazillion bullets hit their mark when the bad guys were firing. (see Arnold, Sly, etc.)  It was suspenseful, the action scenes were well crafted, and I felt that I had spent my money wisely when I purchased that first movie.  Why am I spending time reliving the first movie?  Well, the second movie was just about a carbon copy of the first one!  Now, I understand that they intentionally wished to use the formula that worked so well in "Taken", but I thought they were just a tad bit insulting by asking us to sit through another movie that should have rather been titled "Taken 1.1"!  I gave the movie three stars because it was still fun to watch, and because I like watching guys my age (60'ish) appear invincible!

This film does little more than fortify the Hollywood tradition (clich) of the sequel.  Sure, there have been anomalies, but too many, like this, are [censored by Amazon].  The actors are of course quite good -- in other films.  That would include the original Taken, but let's not delude ourselves, it was significantly shy of being anything more than a chunk of entertainment with at least one relatively memorable scene.  BTW, was anyone looking for a Palme d'Or candidate in this one?  I admit that I was looking for a minor escape, but found myself watching the time, waiting for it to be over.  So, am I comparing this film to the experience of a difficult bowel movement?  Well, all I can really say is that the auteur responsible for Transporter 3 owes me, that's right.  Aside from being a waste of my cash, potentially solid performances, great locales, etc., were likewise squandered in a vapid exercise.  If you're r-e-a-l-l-y interested in these characters, I'd wait until it shows up as a bargain rental (or on Netflix ;).  I actually apologize, Olivier Megaton!  I might have blown my title (and some other statements) out of proportion -- much like the ads for this movie, as I recall.  It was, at best, a mild BM.  Salut.

Yes, he's supposed to be this highly trained, well-prepared operative, but he seemed to breeze through a decently sized opposing force with barely any trouble.  I also wish they had perhaps substituted another character for his ex-wife because she really didn't serve a purpose except to keep Neeson's character fighting just a bit longer.  Considering she hardly had any dialogue and spent most of the film incapacitated it would have been better perhaps if they had fleshed out someone Neeson's character was supposed to be protecting and have them be abducted alongside, giving more depth to his supposed background since we never really see him protecting people other than his family except in small increments.

The original "Taken" was a fast paced, riveting revenge flick that offered brief entertainment, provided you could look past its bizarre flaws (the primary one being a rather racist tone). This sequel contains some of what made the first movie good- Liam Neeson is a hardcore BA, conveying a sense of authentic, lethal ability that is achieved through wisdom and experience, as opposed to high flying kicks and theatrics. All of his combat techniques are ugly, as opposed to being choreographed for beauty, and therefore feel grounded in reality. Neeson's performance is quite good, for the most part, though even he can't erase some particularly bad lines of dialogue that were written for him (a tradition that was established in the original "Taken").

This movie could have succeeded, but it suffers from a plot that is so disjointed, it's downright weird. It's almost as if the writers were just phoning it in on this one, so as to have the means to create another revenge movie. Nothing wrong with that, necessarily, but it's so disjointed, it almost feels surreal... like the characters are stumbling around in a dream. "Taken 2" offers some moderate entertainment for an hour and a half, benefiting from some decent action sequences and the presence of Neeson, but it ultimately proves forgettable. It is, unfortunately, a pale imitator of the original, and watching it only made me wish that I had spent that time watching the first "Taken" again, or something else entirely.

There are two types of sequels in Hollywood - the ones that get made because there's more story to tell and the ones that get made because the first film made a lot of money. At first Taken seemed like it was getting a sequel because it made a bunch of money - but in fact Taken 2 had a good enough idea behind it that I felt there was easily more good story to be told. With the premise of the families of the bad guys in the first film going on an offensive to get back at Bryan Mills was excellent! This premise gives both sides of the conflict the same motivation of protecting their families - which is universal and pretty cool for an action film premise.

The problem is with Mills' entire family in peril - the director keeps the viewer in touch with the family throughout - so we lose that sense of urgency that the first film provided. In the first film we don't see his daughter after she's kidnapped - and it's intense throughout the film because we don't know what's happening to his daughter. This lack of suspense really takes one of the best elements that made the first film such a hit and replaces it with action sequences which suffer due to the lack of urgency and suspense. It's a big problem - there should've been another element added to replace the lack of suspense problem - as just action cannot fix this.

FYI - This paragraph has nothing to do with the movie itself. I think - the bad guys should've just hired another assassin to get Mills and have it become more of a Die Hard, Bourne film cat and mouse game between Mills and an equally talented bad guy. We would've known Mills could win - but since we hadn't already seen him succeed in this kidnap scenario before the intensity needed to be amped up in a different way by taking Mills out of his element a bit. They need someone who can challenge Bryan Mills' level of preparedness so the viewer could feel like they are seeing something worth the "certain set of skills" Mills has.

Anyway - the action was good (not great) Luc Besson knows how to orchestrate a good action film and Olivier Megaton is a solid director for action films - the pacing felt a little stop-start but it wasn't egregious. Overall the film lacked what could've been a great sequel based on the story needing to be expanded and made it feel like a sequel that was out for more cash.

I had heard horrible things about "Taken 2" and reluctantly rented it when there wasn't anything else that interested me. While not quite as good as the first film which blew on the scene somewhat unexpectantly, "Taken 2" still manages to be breezy entertainment with Liam Neeson dong what he does best in action films--beating the bad guys at their own game.

SPOILERS:

While in Istanbul ex-CIA agent Bryan Mills (Neeson), his ex-wife (Famke Janssen--somebody give this underrated actress another film with some substance--please!) are kidnapped by the father (Rade Serbedzija)of one of the men he killed in the first movie. Mills must rely on his daughter Kim (Maggie Grace who, at 27, is getting a wee bit too old for these roles)to help him escape and rescue his wife.

END OF SPOILERS:

"Taken 2" certainly doesn't break any new ground and it's not the unexpected back-to-basics thriller that the first one was but it's enjoyable on its own terms. The action sequences are well directed although this film, unlike the first, seems a bit like all the other recent action thrillers released in terms of staging and stunts. The editing is a bit more choatic, again, much like most of the other action films we've seen over the last decade and while does a adequate job, he lacks the flair of Pierre Morel who made the first film.

Having said that, it is tough to direct a sequel to a popular film like "Taken" because the expectations the first film (which came as a bit of a surprise to many) aren't there. "Taken 2" is still fun particularly as a mindless way to spent a rainy afternoon or if you're at home sick.

The blu-ray looks particularly nice particularly some of the beautifully shot establishing shots of L.A. and Istanbul. Detail is abundant and there's quite a bit of detail evident in this crisp presentation of the film.

The audio is equally impressive with a nice, immersive soundtrack with dialogue STILL remaining clear. We get a variety of subtitles for the film including English, Spanish and, of all things, Mandarin.

The special features includes a "Black Ops Field Manual" (this is only available on the unrated version) which acts as a clever pop up option with background info on the film.

We also get deleted scenes and alternate ending that provides an interesting, slightly different taste to the conclusion of the film.

We can also browse through Mills' weapons case and learn about each one.

"In Character with Liam Neeson" is from FX Movie Channel and is a fluff piece where the actor discusses his character.

We also get the theatrical trailer and, for those using BD Live, Fox gives them an exclusive making of featurette which I didn't watch.

Is "Taken 2" a worthwhile investment to buy? That depends on how much of a fan of this film you are. It certainly is entertaining and engaging.

I have no complaints about Taken 2. It was far better than I thought it would be. It was just as action packed as the first movie, and I believe for a sequel the story was just as good. I will be the first to tell you that a sequel is not going to be better than the first, but this has got to be one of the best sequels of the last 10 years or so. I can honestly tell you that I would put it evenly with Taken 1. This is probably because at the beginning of the movie they made sure to make it have as much character development as the first movie. It really felt like they wanted to truly continue the story of what would happen to a family after the events of the first movie had taken place, and they even brought back the entire supporting cast from the first. They didn't just try to put more explosives and more action and less character development which is the mold that 99% of sequels seem to take. If you enjoyed Taken then I don't believe there is anyway that you won't enjoy Taken 2.

POSSIBLE SPOILERS FOLLOW
Ok, Taken was a great action movie.  It was fresh, it was action packed, and it starred a formidable character, the former CIA Agent Bryan Mills.  While the sequel isn't as good (very few sequels are), it's good at what it's meant for - a vicious, unrelenting action/revenge movie.

Bryan Mills has just finished an assignment in Istanbul, when his ex-wife Lenore (who's having marriage problems with her current rich husband) and his daughter Kim, surprise him at the hotel.  The movie gets crazy quick, as family members from the slain Albanians from the first film attempt to snatch all three.  They succeed with Bryan and Lenore but fail to snatch Kim, due to a call from Bryan.

Through guiding Kim, Bryan is able to help her aid in his escape, fight his way through bad guys, and so the movie goes.  It culminates after an hour of fist-fights and more gunplay with a great Krav Maga-style fight between Bryan Mills and the right-hand man of Murad, the Albanian Mob Boss.  Bryan then confronts and kills Murad, and leaves with Lenore to rejoin Kim.

For plot, the movie feels less effective than its predecessor, but for action, it is well-paced and enough to serve its purpose as an action movie.

Dont even get me started on the slow fighting action scenes; I think the director forgot to speed up the film speed.

Being a huge fan of the first Taken, I was extremely skeptical of how the sequel would turn out. Knowing how Hollywood works, if there is a formula that works, Hollywood would take the liberty and try to milk the cow until it completely dries up. The original Taken (although not a  perfect film) was a great action thriller that had a simple premise but also had characters that were entertaining to watch thanks to the leading role of Liam Neeson.  The first film was about one man practically going against an entire army, going through whatever it takes to save his kidnapped daughter. Yes it was a very simple plot, but personally I found the execution to be thoroughly entertaining to watch.  The action was stellar, the scenarios were well thought out and most importantly you were watching the movie to the very end to make sure Liam Neeson's character does save his daughter.

4 years later comes the release of Taken 2, the direct sequel. One thing I did appreciate about Taken 2 was the fact that the story didn't pull off a "Hangover 2" and just recreate the same movie in a different location. The plot, although familiar, was actually well thought out, and I believe that whomever took the time to write Taken 2 really thought of the best possible way to connect this film and the first Taken.  HOWEVER, what went wrong was simply the way the film was executed. The execution was very poor to say the very least and the director of this film should be ashamed of himself. Just about everything that made the first Taken so great, has suffered immensely in this second film. The only thing that saves this film from being absolute trash was the presence of Liam Neeson, but even he wasn't in top form. The acting from everybody including the great Liam Neeson felt incredibly flat; I just didn't feel the same sense of urgency as I did watching the first film which is awful because this movie is labeled as a thriller. The action sequences were horrid as well; I was glad I didn't catch this in the theaters because I am 100% sure that all the shaky fight scenes would have given me a headache. None of the villains in this movie were memorable whatsoever, I couldn't tell one guy from the other with the exception of the father of the sons Liam Neeson killed in the first movie, but I just didn't find him menacing, just annoying.

As I am a fan of the first film, I found that Taken 2 was without a doubt an unnecessary movie that should not have been released. There were few instances where I found that the film succeeded as far as the plot, mainly in the middle of the film where Liam Neeson was instructing his daughter on how to find the location of him and her mother, but ultimately those scenes could not justify an entire 90 minutes of film. The film felt rushed and the acting was not done well at all; maybe if it was directed by a different person the film would've turned out decent but sadly this is what we have to settle with.

The main plot idea was perfectly reasonable if not a little predicable.  Shortly after Taken 1 the family of the Albanian mobsters that were previously killed go out for revenge and this time the whole family is involved.  It was a mindless action flick, and I wasn't bored while watching it.  Unfortunately this sequel lacked a lot of what made the first one good enough to warrant a sequel in the first place.

Firstly, I found the settings very limited.  Where the first movie felt like it ranged all over Paris, with LN having to work for every clue, this one just had LN chasing someone down one dirty ally or hallway after another.  The action scenes also followed the recent trend of shaking the camera like a martini and shooting disjointed and unrelated things to add a sense of action, then over-using jump cuts to splice the mess back together.

A lot of the plot specifics didn't add up or were too convenient to be believable.  I won't ruin it by running them down specifically here.  Let's just say that unless you think a teenager can drive a cab though barricades and several 50 caliber machine guns to break into a US embassy, an LA girl struggling for normalcy that just narrowly escaped sex-slavery in France will want to travel to Istanbul to "get away", or villains will always do the cliche "I'm just going to leave you alone now in a locked room by yourself even though I know you've single-handily killed all my previous men" then you might have plot issues with this movie too.

One last nit-pick...who ever directed the lighting of this movie must have thought all of Istanbul uses cheap, dim, green-casting florescent lights inside.

Other than all that LN and FJ were good as always, and it was nice FJ had a bigger role in this one.  I just wish I had waiting for the rental to be cheaper or to go free/prime before I watched it, and unlike the first one, I probably won't be watching this one again ever.

The movie itself was good.  I gave it one star because I continue to have issues with Amazon's instant downloads not playing in HD off my xbox 360.  My bandwidth is not the issue as I can view other services like Vimeo in HD without trouble.  Something about Amazon's service is not allowing HD to work, and I'm done with it as a result.  If they're going to advertise it working in HD, then it should work in HD.  This is of course in addition to Dolby Digital not working on the xbox either.

On first inspection it would seem that Luc Besson runs a factory these days that dispenses one action movie after another. He has a stable of directors, cameramen, composers, editors, etc. that go from one product to another. there is a lack of imagination these days coming from the man behind the Fifth Element and the Professional, two great films that were more than a decade ago.
 Besson's latest director to hand films off to for assembly seems to be one Olivier Megatron, who helmed the mundane Transporter 3 and last year's excruciatingly dull Columbiana. To say that Taken 2 is his best effort so far isn't as much of a compliment as it sounds, it's more like stating a fact with little zeal.
 Taking place soon after the events of 2008's Taken, this time around the retired splenetic CIA man Bryan Mills (Liam Neeson) is vacating in Istanbul, Turkey when his daughter, Kim (Maggie Grace) and ex-wife, Lenore (Famke Janssen), pull a surprise appearance. At the same time, the family of the cast of villains from the first movie come looking for some settling of scores. The new crop of Albanian heavies are led by Murad (Rade Serbedzja), the father of one of Neeson's targets the first time around.
 Mills and Lenore are taken hostage, while Kim searches for them. A sort of reversal of events from the last time around. Eventually, Mills escapes with his daughter's help and some handy grenades. He plots his own mission of ruthless revenge and retribution.
 Like it's predecessor, there is a lot of slick action here, everything is fairly neat and tidy, probably too much so. The action sequences are well staged, but there is an over emphasis on quick cut editing to assist the 60 year-old Nesson get through his physical work, that leaves the audience a little nauseated and dazed. Suspense is built through the menacing score by Nathanel Mechaly and the chases scenes are enhanced by solid editing. The camerawork from Besson regular Romain Lacourbas is decent, but workman like. They are also enough car crashes her to make Burt Reynolds salivate. I guess the anonymous stunt drivers should get some credit, good job guys.
 Once again the whole show really is Liam Neeson, an actor too good for this sort of material which he seems to do a lot of now, but he adds dignity and enhances what is essentially a 21st century Charles Bronson role. He works his way through some awkward situations and recycled dialogue from the first movie, but handles it with class that makes this more a pleasure to watch than it really deserves to be. Neeson, should get some better roles soon though, if he wishes to avoid following Nicolas Cage's poor example.
 Maggie Grace is unfortunately just too old for this role, she was too old the first time around, here she is really too old, like Channing Tatum-Jonah Hill too old. She's supposed to still be in high school and studying for her driving exam, but looks to be in her mid twenties. I usually don't complain about such things, except in cases like this where it becomes distracting. She also seems a little more awkward with her acting than before, perhaps because her character is so underwritten that she comes across as a little less than a half-wit.
 And poor Rade Serbedzja, a Serbian leading man and a fine actor, who is sadly given very little to do in a movie such as this. Much like the first go around, Taken 2 suffers from the lack of a strong central villain. There are plenty of anonymous badies for Neeson to off, but no one to create a real lasting impression. Action and thrillers are often made by a strong antagonist, think how James Bond movies are often defined by their villains.
 Famke Janssen, like last time, is again strictly window dressing.
 Megatron would appear to be the least of the filmmakers working in the Besson group these days, which makes it rather peculiar that he would place such an important title as Taken 2 in his clearly incapable hands. At least Pierre Morel, director of the previous movie had reasonably impressive skills at storytelling and greater strength in his dynamics.
 The script written by Besson and his frequent collaborator Robert Mark Karmen, who also wrote the first movie, is nothing to great either. Plodding and rehashing the original film a whole lot, when they aren't reusing situations and even dialogue, they at times resort to flashbacks.
 Overtly stylish like it's popular, but somewhat overrated predecessor, the Taken movies aim for a macho toughness like action pics of the past, but allow themselves to be undone by their anemic bloodletting and safe for mass consumption PG-13 violence, even in the unrated version. These movies lack the edge that it so desperately desires.
 Yet, at a well paced and reasonable length of ninety-two minutes, everything moves at a fast enough pace to forgive much of it's short comings, which there are many.  Taken 2 fails to make us care much about the characters or events on screen, but keeps us reasonable entertain none the less. But let it be known that where the first movie was an old song played at a different tempo, this time around it's strictly a cover version.

In this fast-paced sequel to the hit 2008 action yarn, Liam Neeson returns as the ex-intelligence agent with a "very particular set of skills" and a disdain for those who threaten his family. Targeted for revenge by associates of the (many) men he killed in the first film, he and his ex-wife (Famke Janssen) are kidnapped in Istanbul. Neeson escapes with help from his daughter (Maggie Grace) and together they must race against time to rescue Janssen. Rade Serbedzija, Leland Orser also star. Great movie, Love Liam Nelson. Well worth the watch.

If you want a script that you can't predict the story, that has a compelling story line, well, keep looking. This isn't it.

Byran Mills (Liam Neeson) is in the protection business using his skills that he learned in the CIA to protect wealthy people for a lot of money. His family life is a wreck as he is divorced and his daughter lives with her mom. After rescuing his daughter in the first Taken film he becomes a target of international terrorists who seek revenge for the deaths of their family members (Sons) at the hands of Bryan who killed them as he rescued his kidnapped daughter.

As Bryan's ex-wife and daughter meet up with him in Istanbul the terrorists gather to enact plans to kidnap them all and have the added joy of torturing his family in front of him...

Liam Neeson does his regular spectacular best in this movie playing the highly skilled ex-CIA agent on a mission to save his family. There are many good chase scenes, gun battles and fights to entertain any action movie junkie. I really enjoyed them. The only down side for me is that Bryan puts his daughter at risk and despite the fact that he had a communication device neither he or his daughter sought out help from the CIA or the US Embassy to rescue them.

So the kiddies will not be traumatized? Believe me, if we, the parents, survived so will the kiddies. Oh, I can't write about the stupidity of it all. What for? Liam, don't do this again. OMG, there's still two sons alive and they will seek revenge: maybe "Taken 3" is already being written!

When I saw the trailer for Taken 1 in the theater, I rolled my eyes and figured it would be terrible.  After watching it, I was pleasantly surprised.  I thought it was a well made movie, simple, yet thrilling.  When I saw the trailer for Taken 2, I was very excited to see the follow up story.  The movie is a follow up story, however it is not in the same class as the original.  There really is no spoiler alert, it's the father of the main Albanian guy (Marco) looking for revenge.  People get taken, they escape, and bad guys die.  Taken 2 was basically the complete opposite of the original.  Taken 1 had little buzz, but with low expectations it ended up being great.  Taken 2 had more buzz and high expectations, but ended up being a major disapointment.  After watching it, I felt suckered into watching a movie that was created because the makers knew they would make money on it by capitalizing on the success of the original.  I would highly advise you  not to waste your time.

Liam Neeson reprises his role as a former CIA agent trying to protect his family against a group of Albanian gangsters seeking revenge against him for killing their leader's son in the previous film, "Taken". He's traveling in Turkey with his daughter and estranged wife when the Albanians catch up with him and once again, kidnap his daughter. In his efforts to rescue her and protect his wife, he displays incredible, physical prowess and extraordinary spy craft that belies his age. It certainly helps understand this movie, if you've seen its predecessor. In addition, you must be prepared to suspend disbelief about the hero's abilities

I really wanted to love this movie.  The first Taken was super, and I've been wanting more in the same vein from Liam Neeson since then.  I was happy when Taken 2 finally came out on DVD and ordered it right away, even after reading the negative reviews.  So, it just arrived and I've watched it for the first time.

I'm disappointed and angry at the director.  I think he had a poor concept of what the end result of his decisions would look like.  The super-fast camera angle changes during fights in particular were a big mistake.  In fact, I can't think of anything he did right.

The acting is great, of course.  The whole cast is superb.  Actually, everything about this movie is first-rate, except for the directing, and if I were rating based on that alone, I would have to give it a 1 since that's the lowest Amazon rating.

I don't regret buying it, but I wish I'd waited until the price went down some.  I got it at $14.95, and the price will drop, probably pretty quickly, when the distributors realize they'll have to drop their price in order to sell all their stock.

So, buyer beware.  This movie is not nearly as good as the first one.  It's worth owning if you really enjoy watching Liam Neeson take out bad guys and be a hero.  But read the reviews that detail all the bad points about the directing and believe them.  If you still want to own it, as I did, and if like me, you haven't seen it yet, then at least you'll not be unaware when you watch it for the first time.  My recommendation, though, is to rent it first, and decide for yourself how much you like it.  I didn't rent it first because I'm that much of a Liam Neeson fan.

Taken 2(released Sept/12) stars Liam Neeson as Bryan Mills,Maggie Grace as Kim Mills,Famke Janssen as Lenore, and others. Neeson is back in his role,from the first film,as a retired special agent with "many skills".The action,when it roles,is fast and furious and the production team makes good use of the booming bass lines and noise emphasis that has become so popular in films these past few years,to "enhance" the on screen action. I have a problem with this film,but let's get into the plot first.
The story has us all reunited with the Mills family in L.A.,and this time around there are two converging plots. One is that Neeson's ex is having problems with her new beau and his daughter is trying to get out of taking her driving test that she and daddy have been working on for some time. We switch over to a funeral in Albania where the father,a crime boss,and father of one o the kiddnappers from the first film,is laying to rest his son along with the others Neeson killed the first go round. The father wants revenge and revenge he shall get.
Back in L.A.Neeson is off to Istanbul,Turkey to provide security for a wealthy Arab sheik. He had asked his ex and daughter to come along,but not hearing anything,flew over alone. He is surprised,once his work is done,to have them walk in on him in the hotel lobby. About 30 minutes into the film the Albanians follow and finally kidnap both Neeson and his wife. His daughter is back at the hotel in the swimming area. The couple have hoods over their heads in the kidnap van,but the ever vigilant Neeson counts the miles and keeps track of sounds he hears. They arrive at kidnap central and the wife is cut on the neck and turned upside down in chains to bleed to death,while Neeson,shackled,has to watch. Neeson has a small phone hidden and manages to call his daughter to tell her what has happened and to get to her fathers hotel room a.s.a.p..The kidnappers come but don't find her.
Neeson and daughter reconnect and Neeson has his daughter plotting points on a map and throwing grenades to see how fast the sound reaches Neeson's ears. In short order his daughter has a fix on dad and finds the very chimney that falls down into his room. Neeson has meanwhile freed his wife and the gun his daughter throws down provides him with some defense. His daughter gets chased over rooftops by the kidnappers while Neeson leaves his wife to help his daughter. This he does and both commandeer a cab and return to the kidnap location. Neeson goes in but his wife has been taken away. Neeson and daughter are chased through the narrow Istanbul streets until they are able to reach the U.S.Embassy there and safety. Neeson leaves his daughter to return to find his wife.
Neeson retraces his original trip in the van and finds kidnap central where his wife is. He fights his way in,finds his wife and leaves her once more to get to the leader. Neeson gives the man a choice to stop following he and his family,or otherwise be killed. When the man nods in agreement he drops his gun and the man picks the gun up and fires an empty gun at him. Neeson had of course taken the last bullet out. Neeson dispatches the father tout suite. The film ends with the family enjoying a dinner on,what looks suspiciously like,the Malibu Sports Fishing Pier.
The film certainly has a lot of action to it and Neeson is stone cold,smart and calculating as before. However the prerequisite for an action film is believability. The first one had it in spades,that's why it was so good. This one had some disturbing lapses that had me mentally saying "c'mon,you just didn't do that?".One moment is when Neeson's daughter is fleeing their hotel and she goes straight to the basement,like she knows where she's going,she enters an employee locker area,opens one up and puts on the clothes inside(as to blend in) and leaves. I have never seen a better FITTING ensemble than she had on when leaving. That was NOT believable. Another issue is that of Neeson's daughter and her lack of driving license. It is assumed that she and her dad had been practicing for months in his car,but she had avoided getting her license. To top that knowing that most of the cars in California are automatics,it boggles the mind to watch her drive the stolen cab in narrow Istanbul streets like she was a pro,AND uses a stick shift,which she,at least as far as we know,knows nothing about!!?? Then there is the matter of Neeson's wife and her kidnapping. The fact that Neeson left her once to help his daughter is bad enough,but leaving her again is just so out of Neeson's character as to be totally unbelievable. It is funny that I bring this up because this DVD has an alternate ending to it,which I prefer. In it Neeson doesn't leave his wife the second time. In that version instead Neeson,after having helped his daughter and having returned to kidnap central to fetch his wife,he does indeed come back with her and all of them flee to the U.S.embassy instead of just Neeson and daughter in the theatrical version. The director has a comment before you watch the alternate ending that he preferred the theatrical cut,but thought this alternate provided better entertainment. Well I think he blew it. The alternate ending is the most believable and is most in keeping with Neeson's character. I could have maybe somewhat overlooked the daughter's cloths wearing and her pro like driving skills with a manual shift,but when the lead character does something that is so totally out of line with what he should normally be expected to do,especially a character like his that is so detailed oriented,then sorry I cannot buy into it.
Technically speaking the film is in its w/s a/r of 2:35:1 and is clear and crisp. Extras include that alternate ending I told you about and an interview with Neeson on his promotional junket for the film.
All in all,though the film has its good action moments and Neeson is in top form in his character,the film falters because of the producers letting the aforementioned incidents of unbelievability sneak into the film. I cannot fathom why the director,if they really KNEW the character of Bryan Mills,would they prefer a version that clearly goes against type? For the good of the film's integrity,the theatrical version's ending should have been the alternate,not the other way around.

I liked it a lot. One hopes for a return of a great story when they make a sequel. It doesn't happen here.

All the actors are back except for the rich husband who is now breaking up with Bryan Miles' (Liam Neeson) ex-wife, played by Famke Janssen. Miles suggests she and the daughter played by Maggie Grace join him in Istanbul after his little security gig is over. Of course, neither of them learned their lesson about staying home the first time and they surprise daddy in Istanbul so this plot can continue.

Sure enough they are followed, chased, fight and are captured i.e. Liam and Famke are caught by the family and extended family of the evil pandering, slave-trading, corrupt no-goodniks from Tripolie (pron. Tri-pool-ya), Albania who he killed in Paris in the first film. They manage to find out who he was by beating the French cop, and then by paying off someone in Tirana to find out where he was. As luck would have it, just over the border.

With a secret cell phone, Neeson manages to call his daughter who is hiding in the hotel from her would-be captors. She refuses to save herself and bravely states: "I can do this, Dad."

A 10th grader could have written a better story which held no surprises, hokey dialogue and implausible scenes like Liam talking to his daughter on his cell phone while he has a gun on someone and they have guns on him and his ex. They just stand there! Even the Krav Maga and Hapkido scenes were hard to follow and that 50 caliber machine gun would have split that car down the middle faster than a buzz saw.

You might ask several questions, as I did. How did someone in Tirana know that Bryan Miles would be in Istanbul? How did his captors not find the mini-cell phone? Why were their captors leaving them there tied up, to marinate? How come his ex-wife didn't scream at him at the end for asking her to join him in Turkey? How come this director wasn't traded to the Albanians for some future player to be named later?

This movie needs massive resuscitation. Only Liam's acting skill and his ability to portray a loving tender father and ex-husband while schizophrenically opening a severe can of whupas give this film a faint heartbeat.

My advice is to stay away from Taken 2 or you will be had.

By Jim Clark, publisher, Lee County Courier, Tupelo, Mississippi

You may need to watch Taken again before embarking on Taken 2, since the stories are related.
Bryan Mills (Liam Neeson), a retired intelligence agent, is having relationship problems with his wife, Lenore (Famke Janssen) because of his troublesome career. His daughter, Kim (Maggie Grace) loves him but can't stand his scrutiny of her boyfriends.
Murad, the father of Marko, who Bryan electrocuted in the first Taken, has sworn to avenge the death. He plans to kill all three of the Mills.
The family is supposed to go out together in Istanbul. Kim says she wants to stay by the pool, in a veiled attempt to give her father and mother some alone time.
Bryan notices the couple are being followed, so instructs his wife to get out. She gets captured forcing Bryan to surrender, but not before calling Kim and warning her.
He wakes up strapped to a pole, but able to contact Kim with a phone he's concealed. He wants her to go to the U.S. Embassy but Kim convinces her father that she can help. He instructs her to go back into the hotel and retrieve his suitcase, which is filled with grenades, guns and the like.
I'll admit that Taken 2 leaves reality on the shelf after this point, but for action/adventure junkies it's still a must-see.
Never mind that Rotten Tomatoes gave it a 21% rating.
It grossed $139,548,476 in North America, and $232,044,000 Internationally, meaning a total of $371,592,476. I suspect the DVD release will just add to that bankroll.

I rated Taken 1 a five star. If I were not a die hard fan of Neeson I would have rated Taken 2 at most a two. I had no expectation that the screenwriters could produce something as striking and creative in Taken 1 like the phone conversation by Neeson to his daughter hiding from the kidnappers under the bed, the moves of Neeson to locate his daughter and how he beat several bad guys at the same time in a small area. However, I did anticipate Neeson, with the help of cinematography, to be as outstanding as Craig in James Bond and Damon/Renner in Bourne. Pity that the car chase, the gun fight and particularly the fist fight scenes (the camera kept on swinging that one could make no sense how they really fought at all) were all sub-standard and of far lower quality than its predecessor. Apparently, the change of the director and the choice of Istanbul (a scene was nearly identical with one in "International" by Clive Owen) were not good moves.

I'm feeling generous tonight so will give this movie two stars for the pretty decent action scenes, and the dramatic backdrops of Istanbul. And admittedly, the acting could have been worse. My real gripe with Taken 2 is that I was so distracted by all the ridiculous plot problems and inconsistencies that I couldn't enjoy the action. From the (straight out of central casting) Albanian mobsters speaking English amongst themselves, to the shameless product placements (Toyota, Mercedes, Apple, etc.), to daughter Kim conveniently finding Neeson's weapon stash in an adjacent (but not his) hotel room... and never mind the ridiculous "U.S. Embassy" scene in which Neeson and his daughter crash through a barricade manned by armed Marines, penetrate the "embassy" compound, and are able to just walk away free minutes later--one presumes in real life there would be some serious 'splainin' to do, if not also a lot of paperwork.  My wife tells me that Taken (the original) was a great movie. To be honest, I just don't remember. But I can say with absolute confidence that it must have been better than this dreadful sequel. This is one of those rare movies where I feel like I got ripped off paying only $4.99 to stream it (in HD) at home.  Come on, Liam!

I enjoyed the first Taken movie so I was excited to see Taken 2. Unfortunately it's not even close to being as good as the first film. Taken 2 suffers from sequelitis! They felt they needed to make a second film because of the success of the first and it shows. It feels like the entire film was rushed from conception to production right away. The story is just a terrible copy from the first but with zero depth. The whole idea that a criminal organization would want to get justice for the families of the people you killed just seems stupid to put it mildly. Since when did people who kidnap young women and sell them to the highest bidder for prostitution have morals? Do their families think they were killed selling Bibles or something? That's how stupid the entire premise of Taken 2 is. The leader wanting revenge for Liam Neeson killing all the people from the first film is just absurd.

This film is a sequel to Taken and like most sequels (except for the Goodfather) is not as good as the first movie. Surprisingly, it has nothing to do with the acting or the story but with the direction.

The plot is simple and happens in Istanbul. The father of Marco from Tropoa wants revenge. He puts together a band of thugs from his third world country and comes to Istanbul where he has access to everything: from the government officials to the police (people in third world countries help each other...). Byan Milles (Liam Neesom) is vacationing in Istanbul with his ex-wife and daughter. His ex-wife just got separated from her husband.

The movie had potential and the acting of all participants is really outstanding. However, the direction is really terrible. The fight scenes are really well done but the views from one cameras to the other are multiple and unnecessary. I don't know who did the final cut of the movie, but the person is totally incompetent. And that started with the opening titles, when the bodies are flown to Albania. There are so many camera angles/changes that make you really dizzy. At first I said, OK this it is an exception, poorly done but just the beginning, it will get better. Absolutely not! During the first fight in the market, just before he is taken, I had to close my eyes several times and look away because it made me dizzy and I wanted to puke.  I am not sure who decided to have 20-30 cameras for one fight and have an angle shown from each one at least once, but that was a bad idea; it is a total failure. I have seen Colombiana which was directed by Olivier Megaton and I know Luc Besson was involved in the making of the movie. Never had any problems with Colombiana and I have seen several movies by Luc Besson (the Big Blue, the Fifth Element) and was really happy with his plot and direction. I was really surprised by these deficiencies in this movie.

Zero stars for the direction, five stars for the acting and four stars for the script. Overall three stars.

Taken 3 is in the works. Hopefully they will choose another director. Please...

What is the point of making a sequel to a film when there is very little potential left for developing the concept of the original? A retired CIA agent Bryan Mills is back and Liam Neeson once again brings gravitas to the role that made him an action star about four years ago, but the script of "Taken 2" (written by Luc Besson and his long-time collaborator Robert Mark Kamen) looks more like a reenactment of the original's story set in a more exotic Istanbul location and seen from a different viewpoint.

The story is simple. Bryan Mills (Liam Neeson) is on business trip in Istanbul, where he is reunited with his ex-wife Lenore (Famke Janssen) and daughter Kim (Maggie Grace). Then a band of vengeful Albanian gangsters led by Murad (Rade Sherbedgia) arrives with guns, to avenge the deaths of the men that Mills killed in "Taken."

Now I am not saying that "Taken 2" is a bad movie. The film is slick and action-packed, though action sequences tend to be less credible and thrilling because of choppy editing and our familiarity with the story. As the original's freshness and novelty is gone, the sequel (that looks more like a remake) is more predictable, treading on familiar paths and not veering into new territory, except when Neeson's character is given a rare moment to show his vulnerability.

After all, if there is one reason you should see "Taken 2," it is Liam Neeson showing what a talented actor like him really can do. You know exactly where the story is going, and what his character will do, but at least he does it effectively.

2008's TAKEN was a breath of fresh air: an action film that didn't take itself too seriously, but at the same time wasn't necessarily an homage or parody.  It presented Liam Neeson as an unlikely action hero: where he had previously seemed tall and gangly, now he was broad-shouldered and menacing, a force to be reckoned with.  And thanks to Neeson's charisma, his everyman Bryan Mills shined brightly enough to eclipse any non-PC ethics his role may have raised (Daddy is always right, and little girls should not go abroad without male protection).

Well, if you liked TAKEN, you'll like TAKEN 2...because it's basically the exact same thing.  Minus a star for originality; let's face it, that's a given.  Minus half a star for a rather uninteresting premise: the father of one of the victims from the first film decides to kidnap Mills's family in revenge.  He gets Mills and his ex Lenore (Famke Janssen, returning); however, he misses daughter Kim (Maggie Grace, also back), and as such he underestimates how some traits run in the family.  When Mills gets free (come on, you know he does) , he races the clock to retrieve his wife and dispense justice...or vengeance.  The film doesn't care what you call it.

Sound skeptical?  Well of course it is.  TAKEN required you to suspend your disbelief for a while, and just accept the fact that Mills had "a certain set of skills" that gave him Godlike powers.  TAKEN 2 asks you to throw your disbelief out the window and just go with it.  And you do, largely because Maggie Grace is given a lot more screen time; she goes from being the victim to a real player, a strong female role that the series desperately needed.  Neeson is still in fine form, of course; never doubt his screen presence.  It's the wholly implausible script, and frantic direction, that ultimately bog the film down.  However, for fans of the first, TAKEN 2 is a nice addition.  Perhaps not required viewing, but damned if it isn't a decent thrill ride.
