TAKEN 2 is an excellent action and suspense drama to a degree. Liam Neeson, brilliant as always, gives a very riveting and convincing performance. He is that eternal man on the edge. He is a man who does not give up and drives harder the more the odds are against him. The action is brilliant and makes up for a script that should have been bolstered up and tightened up. Non-the less, this film is high-octane entertainment though it should have run longer and bolstered the depth of the central characters. The film has a good idea, but falls short.

Basically, this is a decent action movie.  Nothing more.  The story is basic.  Nothing interesting or thrilling.  Taken was spectacular.  I think the reason this movie is not that great is that the daughter and wife get in the way.  We want to see Liam's character do what he does best.  There are not enough fights in this film.  Instead he needs his civilian daughter's help.  Boring.

In fact, the plot falls flat in a few really silly and fundamental ways.

He invites his family (ex-wife included) to a place we all know today is a Muslim trouble zone just waiting to become a launching pad for terrorists.  Why would a wise black ops operative do that?  Silly.  Unless, like most divorced men and women, he was secretly hoping his ex would get captured.  But then that would make this a comedy.

Also, he has all these interesting friends with histories akin to his own, but they NEVER get used!  Why are you showing us his friends??? (Who are played by some really talented actors, by the way).  What a waste of some neat teamwork scenes or innovative spy-in-the-field scenes.

Also, why the hell are we subjected to his daughter's boyfriend?  What plot purpose does he serve?  Don't waste my time.

Lastly, the guys he fights are not very spectacular.  Just a bunch of street bums and thugs really.  Wouldn't it have been interesting if the Chinese or Russians had stepped in to cause a little trouble for an American agent who has evaded them on their own soil and made them look foolish in spy operations of the past?  Maybe some special agents to help out the kidnappers and give Liam's character some real opponents?  As it is, his toughest fight is against a short squat guy who looks like he makes pizza in Hoboken, New Jersey.  And his vanquishing of the main evil antagonist was literally as easy as hanging a coat in a coat closet.  You'll understand when you see it.

The film would have been much better if Liam had been forced to deal with the Mexican cartels who kidnap innocents from America even as we speak.  Leave his family at home.  They appeared in the first movie and that was all we needed to see of them.  Give us some interesting plot twists that involve the the dirty underground of spies and internation criminals or something.  Not a silly vacation gone bad.  Frankly I think if he had lost his traveler's checks and had to search the hotel for them, watching that would have been more entertaining than a few of the scenes that did not make the cutting room floor.

Taken 3 please!  Revitalize this character.  Bring in his friends.  Kill off his annoying family.
it was a great movie, loved it. the action was great and the Liam was great as always...hope to see another one with him in it

The unrated cut runs about 6 minutes longer.  It's definitely a harder cut than the theatrical version, but nothing R-rated.  I'm primarily interested in the storyline differences between the theatrical cut and the unrated cut, so SPOILERS follow below.  Do not read further if you do not want to be spoiled!

1) Makeout scene between Jamie and Kim is longer, nothing explicit, but Kim is unsure about going further physically with Jamie.

2) Bryan calls Sam to have him perform a routine background search on Jamie.

3) The interrogation of Jean Claude is a little more brutal and Murad's chief henchman, Suko (stunt coordinator Alain Figlarz), reveals that one of the deceased in the first movie was his brother.

4) Before Bryan takes his daughter on the fireworks boat cruise, they briefly hit up a dance club first where Kim does a little dancing.

5) After Bryan escapes from his imprisonment and fights Murad's men watching the soccer game, he stabs a man in the throat with his empty gun.  This is pretty brutal.

6) After Bryan shoots Boris who falls to his death with a finger on the trigger, Bryan is attacked by a second henchman who meets the same fate and lands on top of Boris's corpse.

7) Extra shots of Bryan skulking around Murad's hideout looking for Lenore.

8) Additional scenes of Bryan chasing Murad, Suko, and Lenore through the streets of Istanbul.

9) The final fight scene between Bryan and Suko is about twice as long as the theatrical version.  Suko cuts Bryan on the palm with his hidden knife.

10) Most, if not all, of the fist fights between Bryan and the henchmen are longer and more brutal.

11) Additional sound effects, e.g. throat gurgling, neck breakings, etc.., have been re-inserted.

12) Most, if not all, action scenes involving people dying by firearms feature extra rounds fired into the victims.

I enjoyed Taken 2.  Sure, some parts may have been MacGyver-ish, but it's always entertaining to see Liam Neeson beat up henchmen.  WSD, people.  Willing Suspension of Disbelief.  At least the hand-to-hand action scenes were better cut than the Bourne series.

Liam Neeson is a complete badass.  How do you define a 'badass'?  Well, typically all you'd need to do is look at a picture of Chuck Norris and you'd instantly understand.  But, some things change and clearly Liam Neeson is taking over the Hollywood action scene.  If you need evidence, just watch any of his recent films.  What's that?  You hated The Phantom Menace, but Liam Neeson was still a badass?  Absolutely.  He lightsaber duels with the Sith, he kills man-eating wolves, he battles aliens on the ocean - and yes, he even takes time to beat the crap out of common criminals in Taken.

This time, Neeson returns in Taken 2 as Bryan Mills, a former intelligence agent that does security jobs on the side, while trying to maintain a healthy relationship as an over-protective father with his daughter, Kim (Maggie Grace).  Rade erbedzija plays the film's villain, Murad Hoxha, an Albania mobster that is seeking revenge for the death of son (one of the countless thugs Neeson killed in the first film).  Famke Janssen also returns as Lenore, Bryan's ex-wife, who just happens to have recently separated with her most recent husband - naturally prompting a Neeson/Janssen reunion.

If you're looking for a movie with drama or basically any kind of plot-driven substance, this film isn't really for you.  All you really need to do is see the film's trailer and you'll quickly understand how this film is going to go.  Neeson's character and his wife are abducted and it's up to their daughter to help free them.  It's pretty cut and dry, meaning the film is completely predictable from beginning to end.  However, if you judge the film on that merit, you'll hate it and most likely not even spend your money to see it.  The point of this film (and most any film) is to be entertained - by a watered-down James Bond - who's only mission is to retrieve his family, while beat up the bad guys on his way.

Overall, if you're a fan of the first Taken, then you'll definitely want to see the sequel.  Same actors, same action, same premise, etc.  It's a quick 90 minutes, so don't even bother checking the time.  It will be over before you know it, and once you're engaged with all the excitement that this film has to offer, you'll be begging for the next sequel.  And, by all means - bring it on!

Film Grade: B

'Taken 1' was a very good film, 'Taken 2' is so unbelievable that parts are laughable. However, the violence and fast pace kept me immersed in this film. Liam Neeson, plays Bryan Mills, an ex-CIA extraordinaire, his daughter, Kim played by Maggie Grace and Famke Janssen, plays ex-wife to Bryan. First of all, Bryan is more than a helicopter parent, he has a GPS inserted into his daughter's iPhone, so that he can track her. His ex-wife is separated from husband #2, but seems to forget him quite easily, and has her eyes on her ex. Bryan must go to Budapest to guard a sheik, and invites his family to join him after his job is complete. Of course, the father of the bad guys Bryan killed previously in 'Taken 1', has his eyes on revenge. He plans on killing Bryan, and then discovers the entire family is in one place, what a coup! Bryan and his wife are kidnapped, while daughter, Kim stays at the hotel pool. Wife, Lenore is hung upside down with a slow bleed from her neck. Somehow, (this is the unbelievable part) while chained and shackled, Bryan is able to call daughter Kim and gives her explicit directions on how to find them. Not only did Kim fail two driving tests but she is somehow able to travel the streets of Budapest at very high speed, maneuver tight squeezes in the stolen cab and avoid getting them killed. Bryan, meanwhile, kills everyone standing, sitting and hiding. What a guy! what a family! Recommended for the lovers of violence and unbelievable action. prisrob 01-02-13 Five Minutes of Heaven The Next Three Days

Taken 2 is nowhere near as good as Taken. While Taken isn't the most inventive action film, it was very enjoyable and had some genuine excitement. This is not the case for Taken 2. Taken 2 takes the "Bourne" approach even more than the first, utilizing the very cliched shaky cam and quick cuts. Quick cuts are even used in slow dialogue scenes, and for no obvious reason. As an editor myself, I believe cuts should be precise, intentional, and purposeful. As I was studying some of the shots in this film, I came to the conclusion that the editors didn't really put much thought into WHY the cuts were being made, other than to make the film faster-paced, and it didn't work. Also, the director overused high-shutter speed cameras to "intensify" fight scenes. This made me dislike the film even more, as this is an extremely overused technique. This film wasn't just bad technically. The writing was poor. A friend I was with even pointed out some contradictions in the dialogue, causing some serious continuity issues. The writers were very sloppy and it is clear the focus of this film was not on the story or the writing, but the action, which is something a film should NEVER do.

I apologize for not being able to find anything good with this film. Taken 2 is a prime example of what I dislike about action films: fast cuts, shaky cam, and high shutter speeds, not to mention, poor writing and dry acting. This film was obviously action-based with weak characters and a very flimsy script. I would recommend this to anyone who wants to go to the movies and literally be in a coma and not use their brain whatsoever. This is easily a candidate for the worst film of the year.

This movie picks up with Brian taking Kim and Lenoir to Istanbul for a vacation. Lenoir has just divorced and is trying to reform their family bonds. Meanwhile, the families of the dudes Brian killed in Taken 1 come for revenge. This time, Brian and Lenoir are taken. Kim helps them escape and Brian proceeds to murder all the bad guys in the face. That's the plot, not a whole lot of difference from the 1st film.

The difference is the directing and production quality. The director's name is Oliver Megaton. I've met a lot of people, but I've never heard the name, Megaton. I can only assume that this dude went to the courthouse and changed his last name trying to be cool. That is kinda the way this movie felt. It seemed like someone tried to do something cool in a really half baked way. The result was mediocre. If Liam Neeson wasn't the star of this film, nobody would have given it a second thought. Oliver Megaton made a mega mediocre film. Liam Neeson saved it and made it sort of cool. Overall weighing the good and bad, this film is 4 stars in my opinion. It's worth watching once, but I wouldn't want it taking up space on my shelf.

How do you come back from the worst experience in your life? Therapy, denial, maybe some substance abuse? What if, after a relatively short amount of time, you're flung back into a very similar circumstance? I don't imagine that would help.

Sometime after returning to the relative safety of Los Angeles, Bryan Mills (played by Liam Neeson), his ex-wife Lenore (played by Famke Janssen) and their daughter Kim (played by Maggie Grace) are still rebounding from the trauma they suffered. Bryan (Neeson) arrives at Kim's home to give her a driving lesson only to be informed that she is not even in the house. She's with her boyfriend. A boyfriend Bryan knew nothing about, no less. Simultaneously, in Tropoje, Albania, Murad Hoxha, father of deceased kidnapper and human trafficker Marko Hoxha, is attending a funeral service being conducted for his son and his accomplices. Murad (played by Rade Serbedzija) vows to avenge the deaths of his son and his friends. After hearing that a planned vacation to China is cancelled by Lenore's now estranged husband, Bryan invites both Kim and Lenore to join him on a business trip in Istanbul once he's fulfilled his professional obligations. They arrive sooner than expected and, unbeknownst to them, followed by Murad's henchman. Following a family lunch in the marketplace, Kim returns to the hotel. It's immediately apparent to Bryan and Lenore that their daughter hopes privacy and the exotic locale will rekindle feelings of love in her long-divorced parents. While romance does seem to be in bloom between the couple, it is abruptly halted when Murad and his men make their play for the Mills family.

  Now, I was and still am a huge fan of the 2008 film. I believe Neeson took a film that would've seemed dull and uninspired in the hands of Jason Statham, Vin Diesel, or any other contemporary action star and elevated it beyond the material. This film, while entertaining and plausible enough for an action/adventure, is the lesser of the two. Of course, there's the fact that it's more of the same and, therefore, less interesting. In addition, while the original depended on Neeson's estimable talent, this film relies heavily on Maggie Grace. A competent actress, sure, but nowhere near as good as Liam Neeson. I enjoyed it about as much as I expected to. That's it.

Also, his inexperienced driver daughter drove like a pro out from the debris of multiple car wrecks, which would have rendered any other. (Don't know how they managed to get to the front steps of the embassy) car inoperable. Taken II suffers from the same problem 'Taken I' did. It's big on well choreographed action sequences, has good acting by Liam Neeson, nice locations, fairly good production qualities, directing, etc. But it lacks any common sense at all. Most action films where there are a lot of bullet's flying and car crashes require the viewer to suspend belief to a certain level. But these two films take excessive license with it, and often to laughable levels. I pretty much hated the first one. Though I found it very entertaining on a brainless sort of level with great action sequences, I simply could not get past the rediculous notion that a girl who's father worries something will happen to her get's kidnapped the second she shows up in Paris. She's literally targeted the very moment she lands. That sort of license pushes the envelope so far that it's insulting to the audience's common sense. That particular part of the script and the plot was pathetic and just plain stupid. Also the girl who played his daughter was very plastic and cheesy. I saw Taken II last night and did find it entertaining, and I liked it a little more than I liked the first one, but only because I already realized you have to leave all your brains at the door in order to enjoy it at all. In the first one she's just plastic and annoying. In this one she's not only plastic and annoying, but she's running around on rooftops throwing hand granades all over Istanbul, and driving getaway cars like a pro stunt driver when earlier on in the movie she's studying for her drivers license and can't even figure out how to park right. This one takes more license with the stupidity than the first one for sure. This is sort of like watching a John Woo or Michael Bay movie with slightly better production values. What I mean by that is that Woo and Bay action films usually cross the line into the rediculous and are generally rather out there. But thta is not to say Woo's earlier asian films were bad, they were really ok for what they were. But movies like Armageddon & The Rock for example are generally liked by a lot of people but are also hated by a lot of people. And if you hated those movies then you likely know where I am comming from. This is typical of the formula you expect from a Steven Seagal movie. Lots of action but short on brains. Also when I saw the first Taken I kept imagining Keifer Sutherland playing the main character. To all intents and purposes the Neeson character is a carbon copy of Jack Bauer, still I loved Neeson as this character. In fact without him the film would not be memorable for most people who like it now. The Taken movies play like cheesebal B style action movies, but still on a brainless action level both movies are pretty entertaining. So I hated and liked both movies, hence the 2 star rating.

Viewers of the original "Taken" recall that the Armenian thugs operating in France, who captured and sold Liam Neeson's daughter into sex slavery, got their comeuppance when CIA-trained Dad found them in Paris.  It turns out that those dead twenty-something gang members had relatives who now seek revenge.  And how will they exact it?  Well, there's a reason these movies are entitled "Taken".

This time the locale is Istanbul.  One could reasonably conclude that Director Olivier Megaton had to be mightily influenced by the Bourne Trilogy as there are similarities.  There's lots of action - likely to make up for a predictable plot (I won't give it away, other than to say most viewers will have it figured out in the first 20 minutes).  It's definitely not in a league with the Bourne series, and runs a poor second to the original "Taken."

However, if you liked the original, the action is good and the film fast-paced enough to be an okay flick for a 90-minute viewing.

Spoilers lie below.

Like: Brian Mills isn't super human, we see him actually look like he's struggling in some of the fight scenes. Liam Neeson mentioned in an interview that he didn't want to do the film if it lacked this element since it wouldn't make sense for Brian Mills to take a beating and be perfectly fine at his age. Kudos for this.

Dislike: Cheesy. Mills and his wife get back together. Some of the mushy dialogue. Yuck.

Like: The daughter (who's name escapes me as I type this) serves a purpose.

Dislike: The daughter is still whiny and immature. Listen to your flippin' father! He saved your butt so he obviously knows what he's doing!

Like: The idea of revenge. You can't kill a bunch of people and not anger someone.

Dislike: The villain is an old man... Okay, bonus points for making Liam Neeson have to face someone in his age bracket and for mirroring the situation Mills went through in the first film (loss of child). However, it's almost pathetic... maybe it should've been an uncle? Brother? Brother-in-law? ....anything other than the father of one of the people he killed in Taken.

Like: The fact that there is this gray area of morality brought up by having Mills face the father of someone he killed. Why was his daughter's life worth killing so many people? Shouldn't he face some sort of punishment for his actions? Even if they were bad men, he still took the law into his own hands and killed them.... When there's a gray area like that it makes the film more interesting regardless of what side of the gray area your opinions lie.

Dislike: You set off how many grenades in Istanbul and no one noticed? The city didn't shut down for potential terrorist activity? Huh? Not believable at all.

Overall I decent film, worth watching. Not the best action film ever though... and the original was much better.

Recently watched movie review:
*Taken 2 (2012)- 1/5

Taken 2 is a sequel to the 2008 film (Taken) which is newly directed by Oliver Megaton. It stars Liam Neeson, Maggie Grace, Famke Janssen, and Rade Sherbedgia. I love the first movie, so does Taken 2 live up to my expectations? Ha, it's not even in the same league, and it's the worst movie I've seen so far this year.

Bryan Mills (Liam Neeson) killed a lot of men while searching for his daughter, Kim (Maggie Grace), who was taken in Paris by a human trafficking ring. Family members of the men, whom he killed in the first film, are mourning those who died. Murad (Rade Sherbedgia) who's the employer of the men and father of Marko, a victim whom Bryan killed, swears revenge, and states that they will find Bryan to avenge the deaths of their loved ones. Murad and is men capture Bryan and his ex wife, Lenore (Famke Janssen), while Kim lucks out and helps her parents escape death.

Taken 2 falls flat in every single way possible compared to the awesomeness of the first Taken movie. Let me start off by saying the only good thing about the film... (crickets), (crickets), (crickets)... That's right, there's nothing good to say about it.

There are so many 'I just rolled my eyes' moments in the film, and there's very little that's believable; While Bryan is involved in a gun standoff with Mured's men, the kind men let him whip out his phone to warn Kim that he and Lenore are being taken (I just rolled my eyes). Kim can't pass 2 driving tests, but she can throw grenades, do geometry, jump from rooftop to rooftop, and can drive like a stunt driver in a chase scene (I just rolled my eyes). Murad, who knows Bryan can kill just about anyone, gives Lenore a baby gash, hangs her upside down, tells Bryan, who's tied to a pole, that she's got 30 minutes until she dies, leaves the room with them unattended, and expects everything to go as plan (I just rolled my eyes). When Bryan obviously breaks free and saves Lenore, he later fights some of Murad's men, but somehow he's got special powers this time around; Bryan can simply put his hands on someone's face, and that person will instantly die (I just rolled  myeyes).

The first Taken was far more energetic, there was more dialog, the villain isn't old and pathetic, and events were much more believable. Taken 2 is soulless compared to the first, and should be avoided at all costs as this is a simple cash grab. If you're a fan of the first (like me) and wanted a sequel, use your imagination instead, and continue to just watch the first Taken. If you couldn't tell by now, Taken 2 gets a recommended 'must-pass.'

I'm going to start off by saying how much I love action movies. The Expendables 2 was easily one of the best action flicks I'd seen in a long time and the first Taken is one of my all time favorites. HOWEVER, this movie is a terrible excuse of an action film.

The movie takes up very shortly after Taken ends, with the families of the men Neeson killed in the first film hungry for revenge. The film takes a considerable amount of time to get going but once it does, you want it to stop immediately. The action scenes (which are the core part of a proper action movie) are hideously choreographed and filmed even worse. You can't follow the action because of the 'edgy' camera shake (popularized by Paul Greengrass in the 2nd and 3rd Bourne movie and poorly imitated by every would-be action director out there) but even if you could, you'd be bored by the aforementioned choreography. The first film had frenetic action scenes that were filmed beautifully and packed with brutal and unique disarms and kills. This was just Neeson trudging along from one hapless goon to the next.

Speaking of trudging that's all this film does, from one pointless scene to the next. The only remotely interesting scene is a chase sequence in which Neeson's daughter (Maggie Grace, who was the one bright point of this awful film), who doesn't yet have her driver's license, is driving a taxi cab around this little town like she's Tanner Foust. And even this sequence isn't very interestingly filmed or exciting. If you want to see how a proper car chase is filmed, watch Ronin.

Luckily this train wreck of a movie is over after not very long; once Neeson has disposed of (hopefully) the last henchman in the small town he's terrorized. If you are thinking of seeing this film DON'T. It is a bad movie, but worse than that it is A TERRIBLE ACTION MOVIE that doesn't even remotely compete with the first. Taken 2 is a sequel that no one asked for, and no one deserves to have to see.

-Remember, It's only one man's opinion! (But this time it's the right one)

You won't find any film schools showing this flick, but you will find lots of regular people enjoying it when they sit down to watch.  Liam Neeson is in typical Liam form (at least post-Schindler form), the villains are ugly thugs, and the women are both (no, wait...there is a 3rd woman...she appears twice for a total of about 24 seconds) attractive.  There is plenty of action, and a super-simple story line that drives this 90+ minute film along with nary a wasted camera shot.

This movie is a lot of fun, but it is absolutely ridiculous.  I laughed as I left the theater because of how bad some of the movie is:
1) Liam Neeson's hand-to-hand fighting skills must have atrophied a lot, because every time he is in a fight with a thug (did I mention they were all ugly?) the director uses about 6 camera angles to film the fight, and uses editing so choppy that you can't tell what anyone involved in the fight is doing.

2) Maggie Grace is playing the high-school aged daughter of Liam!  She looks like she's about 30 here, and her bad hair-dye is matched only by her too-brief nude scene (back only, no butt).

3) SPOILER HERE:  The mom is like a character out of the old Monty Python sketch..she is 'not quite dead' about five times in the flick. And every time she's 'not quite dead' all Liam has to do to make her better is pat her back.  It's so funny, that the audience was cracking up the 3rd time it happened.

Overall, this was a fun night at the movies.  I loved how cheesy the movie was, and had a great time.

Her dad, who has been taken hostage, can locate his position by the sound of exploding bombs !

Next time a bomb explodes in your city, stay cool.  It's just the good guy finding his way out.

"Taken 2" is great! This is how the story goes: Bryan Mills is the retired CIA agent with a "particular set of skills" who stopped at nothing to save his daughter Kim from kidnappers. When the father of one of the villains Bryan killed swears revenge, and takes Bryan and his wife hostage in Istanbul, Bryan enlists Kim to help them escape. Bryan then employs his unique tactics to get his family to safety and systematically take out the kidnappers, one by one.

The cast led by Liam Neeson (as Bryan), Maggie Grace (as Kim) & Famke Janssen (as Lenore) is great. The directing by Olivier Megaton is great. The screenplay by Luc Besson (who also produced) & Robert Mark Kamen is great.

The music by Nathaniel Mechaly is great. The cinematography by Romain Lacourbas is great. The film editing by Camille Delamarre & Vincent Tabaillon is great. The production design by Sebastien Inizan is great. The art direction by Nanci Roberts & Atilla Yilmaz is great. The set dressings by Joshua Foster, John Markovich & Franck 'Frenchy' Brousse is great. The special effects coordinated by Donn Markel & supervised by Philippe Hubin is great. The stunts coordinated by Mark Vanselow, Alain Figlarz, Laurent Demianoff & Michel Julienne is great.

This is a great action sequel to a great action movie that is entertaining and fast-paced. Liam Neeson is still as great as ever in his return as Bryan Mills. This is just as great as the first "Taken". This is one of the best movies of the fall season.

When will people learn not to take Liam Neeson's stuff? TAKEN 2 addresses one of the more nagging recurring plot holes in storytelling: What happens when the hero doesn't dispose of all the villains? The sequel opens in Albania with the burial ceremony of those sex-traffickers Bryan Mills (Neeson) had mowed thru in the first film. And there's the terrifying patriarch Murad Krasniqi (Rade Sherbedgia) presiding over their graves and vowing bloody revenge.

Cut to Los Angeles, some time later. Ex-CIA operative Bryan Mills still can't help being over-protective of his daughter Kim (Maggie Grace), which sucks for her new boyfriend. For her part, Kim is still traumatized over her harrowing abduction from around a year ago. While we were away, Mills and his estranged ex-wife Lenore (Famke Jannsen) had achieved a sort of dtente. And when a distraught Lenore admits that her current marriage is speedily crumbling, to try to make her feel better, Mills invites her and Kim to holiday with him in Istanbul where he'll be conducting some security consultant work. Note that Istanbul is practically a stone's throw away from Albania. This is what's known as a foreshadowing observation.

At age one hundred and four Liam Neeson still demonstrates fantastic action chops. He generates such gravitas, his performance has such credibility, you just buy that he's perfectly capable of extricating himself from any form of tight scrape. In Istanbul, Krasniqi marshals his forces and strikes, and yet Mills is canny enough to put gum in the works. He and his wife are taken but, thanks to his timely warning, Kim escapes, if barely. We now arrive at the best segment of the film, when a captured Mills, over a phone he'd secreted away, manages to talk Kim thru the intricate process of determining his unknown location. I won't say much more than that, other than the process involves a shoelace, a map, and grenades. What follows is a nifty sequence that equally illustrates Kim's gumption and vulnerability. It allows Maggie Grace to step out of her thankless role of victim. You may have to be generous in overlooking the ridiculous stuff she gets up to in following her dad's orders.

Again, the lesson to take away here is "Do not take Liam Neeson's stuff!" After the box office success of this sequel there's already talk of a third picture, and I'm down with that. But only if Neeson is a participant. Yes, the sheen brought about by an aged Neeson kicking butt has worn off some, but there's still enough of that luster to make TAKEN 2 a satisfying watch. He abuses more Albanians in this film franchise than Peter Falk ever did in TUNE IN TOMORROW. It's a slick thriller, maybe not a deep one, and it fails to retain the shock value of the first film. It certainly doesn't have anything as memorable as Neeson's awesome "I will find you" speech. But I like the in-jokes referencing the first film. And the acting is across-the-board solid, with Rade Sherbedgia making a perfectly hissable big bad. You know he means deadly business when he bluntly informs Famke: "Mrs. Mills, you are a good mother and a brave woman. For that I am going to send you back home... piece by piece." Oh, yeah, he's a perfect candidate for Liam Neeson's brand of brutal efficiency. After all, he took Liam's stuff. Dude. Must. Pay.

3.5 out of 5 stars.

I very much enjoyed this second go around with "Mills"Just like the first movie,it takes about 10 minutes or more before the action gets going.the tension builds throughout with revenge the ultimate goal.the daughter has grown up and is believable at times,I chuckled with her at the wheel,driving dad while he's shooting.the movie kept my attention all the way and I will add this to my collection when it comes available.

This film is done for the European public first of all but it should work in the USA with the nostalgia of so many action films and of course Midnight Express. But the main difference with this film is that here we do not know why the Albanians and this American security agent are fighting. Albania was on the border of the war in Kosovo. So we know there is a political problem and stake. Albania was the communist country that had absolutely banned all religious activities and all religious expression. So, what's left to keep the Albanians away from kidnapping young girls and women to feed them in their lucrative prostitution network? Nothing, not even religious beliefs to try to repent, at least five minutes a day. And we just learned Albania is getting ready to join the European Community. Really? Yes, so they say in the media.

 Even more surprising is the fact that the action mainly takes place in Turkey, in Istanbul. Turkey wants to join the European Community and the Euro Zone and that's tricky to provide the European public with that totally violent, terroristic and immoral image of Istanbul. Is it trying to ask this question from all Europeans: Are you going to let that country enter the European Community as if they were peaceful and law-abiding? Or is it asking that other question from the Turks: How can you dare to want to enter the European Community when you are not even able to prevent your territory from being used like that by terrorists without any other motivation than their personal vengeance?

The film is ambiguous and very obscure as for its political and ideological motivations. It cannot move the Americans who know nothing about these political questions, but it may frankly be disturbing to the European or Turkish public.

But it is a film by Luc Besson. So there are other elements than just this unclear ideological context.

First it is an action film and Luc Besson here uses an extremely rapid tempo with no slowing down except to increase the suspense and to make us fear the worst. The action is also extremely simple in the means it uses. No super technology. The good old simple cars and car chases, then a simple pager, then some simple guns: grenades, hand guns and some assault automatic guns. That's all. All the rest is simple running and tricky inventiveness. Of course the escape through the window and along a narrow cornice on the faade of a hotel has already been used but its simplicity works perfectly well.

Second Luc Besson has to add a child, here a teenage daughter that should be just over sixteen, since she is trying to get her driver's license and she has already failed twice. Her being in any kind of danger is poignant of course, and her mother being captured and used as bait is just as bad. And Luc Besson cannot evade the clich, but so well done and used, of the father fixation and of that father who saves his daughter first and his wife, at least twice. We remember Lon of course and the little girl he decides to help in her necessary vengeance since all her family has just been executed by some dumb terrorists. That's a syndrome if not a tic or even an idiosyncrasy of Luc Besson's: the father figure that saves the day of a daughter, a mother, a family, a victim of some terroristic gang violence. That gives a touch of empathy.

The end then would not surprise at all and is so typical of Besson again. The daughter is over sixteen and so she is of age. So she has a boyfriend and the father is kind of jealous somewhere, but Besson must be aging since he is able to make the father step back from his protective jealousy concerning his daughter. Charming.

Dr Jacques COULARDEAU

Based on the screen appeal of Liam Neeson and the sex slave trade in Eastern Europe, we give you "Taken 2." In Eastern Europe the action takes place shorty after Bryan Mills (Liam) went "walking tall" all over them to save his daughter in the first feature. They are burying their dead and vow revenge. Yes, slave traders love their children too. In the US, the action takes place at some time in the future from the first film. Liam's ex-wife Lenore (Famke Janssen) is now separated from her husband and daughter Kim (Maggie Grace) with whom Bryan has built a solid relationship by rescuing her from slave traders, is slightly ungrateful as she would now rather spend time with her boyfriend Jamie (Luke Grimes) then let dad give her much needed driving lessons.

In order to make it easy on the script writers, Bryan and family travel to Istanbul. In spite of Liam's alertness, savvy, and being a lean mean fighting machine, his ex-wife is not and they are "taken" because "Kidnapped" has been used as too many film titles. Armed with a cell phone with a Turkish SIM card, a shoe lace, and some government issue grenades, Kim goes McGyver on them to save the family.

Definitely lacks the intensity of the first film. I would wait to watch this one cheap.

Parental Guide: No f-bombs, sex, or nudity.

In which obsessively compulsive CIA veteran Bryan Mills (Liam Neeson) and his estranged family are abducted by a village of Albanian Muslims hell-bent on avenging the other half of the village, whom Mills single-handedly slaughtered in Taken 1. I hadn't had the pleasure of that particular piece of cinema as I took my seat in the Odeon Leicester Square: it turned out not to matter.

We open with a glamorous helicopter shot of an unglamorous Albanian truck, bouncing up a dirt road to a communal hilltop burial ground where, clutching a fistful of dust over his family's manifold fallen, patriarchal villain Murad (Rade Serbedzija) gravely swears vengeance on Mills' head, beseeching most of what remains of his extended family (still handsomely stocked with uncles, second cousins and nephews) to join him.

That Mills only came to be involved after the village kidnapped his daughter Kim (Maggie Grace) and sold her (among others) into slavery does not upset the Albanians' moral calculus. Burial ceremonies complete, they mount a convoy of dusty Mercs and make haste to Istanbul where, as luck would have it, Bryan is attempting a low-key reconciliation with his wife Lenore (Famke Janssen) and daughter (yes: the same one who was kidnapped last time she left L.A: clearly not the lesson-learning type).

Mills' patiently-recounted OCD, which sees him insist on (ahem) polishing his own bonnet at the car wash, seems not to extend to keeping his dependents reasonably out of harm's way: After a scene-setting educational ride across the Bosphorus ("it's where East meets West" etc etc) and the obligatory aerial shot of Istanbul's grand mosque as the muezzin calls the faithful to prayer, the Albanian Mercs roll in. Cue mayhem.

This is big, dumb fun on a Luc Besson scale. As long as you can balance between being neither taking it at all seriously nor finding it entirely absurd (a challenge with which most of the audience, including your correspondent, struggled) it will keep you entertained.

Joyously-named director Olivier Megaton - vraiment de l'ecole Besson - certainly gives it the by name/by nature treatment: many bottomless semi-automatic magazines, carelessly-tossed hand grenades, twisted necks, caved-in skulls, improvised shivs, exploding cars and kick boxing demonstrations are required to progress a surprisingly tedious plot to a very pre-ordained conclusion. Megaton doesn't even bother with a they-think-its-all-over-but-he's-not-yet-dead final scene bad-guy reprise. Instead, proceedings draw to a indecently hasty conclusion, the film ending with a bookend glamorous helicopter shot of - wait for it - the family eating waffles in a pier-end restaurant in Venice Beach. This about says it all.

Why Liam Neeson, a sound actor and surely the sine qua non of the picture, felt at all compelled to make it is a mystery. There is little craft in it, and and the dialogue only works as irony.

Strictly routine.

Olly Buxton

The original Taken was an incredible movie, and Taken 2 has got some incredible moments. The main difference is that Bryan Mill's (Liam Neeson) family plays a much larger role in the sequel. While the first movie is about a lone wolf taking out bad guys like gnats on a summer day to get his daughter back, this one involves the family unit, so the experience, while using incredible action scenes, is a bit different.

There is also a little more down time in this film, as cheesy tender moments are used to work the audience up before mother and father are abducted by a psychotic terrorist hellbent on getting revenge as a result of Bryan killing his son.

This film provides tons of kills, explosions and everything else that makes a movie good, and it has some real cheese in it, leading up to the action you're wanting. I say go see this film. I didn't enjoy it as much as the first one because I'd rather see Bryan go it alone, but this is still a great action film. I liked it enough to want there to be a third installment.

As for the cheese in the film, the script is pretty bad, especially the dialogue between father and daughter, father and ex-wife before the movie gets rolling, but Liam Neeson is a great actor, so he saves it from veering off to Dolph Lundgren or Steven Segal territory (Hey, I'm not saying their movies are bad, just saying the dialogue is).

Anyway, if you love action and like family films, this is the one for you, brother.
